message: Sixteen years ago, America was faced with an attack of unspeakable evil and cowardice that took the lives of thousands of our fellow citizens. The terrorists were gravely mistaken about the resolve and character of the American people. What emerged that day was a bravery and compassion that for centuries has defined the American spirit: first responders racing into burning buildings, everyday Americans sacrificing their lives to protect their neighbors and prevent further mayhem, and the brave men and women who have brought the fight to the enemy and kept the homeland safe. On Patriot Day, let us all vow to remember those who sacrificed to keep us safe, pray for those they left behind, and rekindle the unity that we experienced on that grave day in September.

The lights of Hanukkah remind us how the Jewish community has spread their light around the world and to us here in Alaska. Julie and I wish Alaska’s “Frozen Chosen” a happy and peaceful Hanukkah as we approach the final night of the Festival of Lights.

Julie, the girls and I spent our New Year’s weekend in Girdwood, one of the most beautiful places in the world. Like many corners of our amazing state, Girdwood is a true winter sports playground — downhill and cross-country skiing, skijoring (which I tried out with our family lab, Maddie), and world-class snow machining nearby. We capped off the year with the stunning annual torchlight parade down the slopes of Alyeska followed by a spectacular fireworks show. I hope you had a safe and enjoyable weekend. We want to wish you and your family a 2017 filled with good health, joy and peace. Happy New Year!

The first Alaska statehood bill was introduced by territorial delegate James Wickersham in 1916. Fifty eight years ago today—as a result of tremendous work by Alaskans and some allies across the country who saw our potential—Alaska became the 49th state to join the Union. And since we were admitted, Alaska has contributed greatly to the prosperity and fabric of America with an abundance of resources, a proud and diverse people, and the potential to lead our great nation into new frontiers. I want to wish my fellow Alaskans a Happy Birthday!

Senate leaders today announced committee assignments for all senators in the new term. I’m grateful to be able to serve Alaska on the four committees I started out with, all important to Alaska’s interests: Armed Services; Commerce, Science and Transportation; Environment and Public Works; and Veterans’ Affairs. From strengthening Alaska’s fisheries, advocating for our state’s more than 77,000 veterans, highlighting Alaska’s strategic importance to our national defense, and rolling back onerous regulations that are hampering our economy, I look forward to making meaningful progress in the new Congress for Alaskans.

My office was fortunate to have five exceptional interns these past few months. Anna, Isabel, Xavier, Sydney and Sorcha each rose to the challenges given to them, and were a great help to me and my staff. Expect to see more from these young Alaskans in the future. If you are looking for a post-high school opportunity to challenge yourself and gain great life experience in our nation’s capital, please visit sullivan.senate.gov/services/internships and share with your friends!

I had the pleasure of meeting with President elect Trump’s nominee for ambassador to the United Nations, Governor Nikki Haley of South Carolina. Governor Haley emphasized the need to reassert American leadership at the UN, and restore confidence among our allies, like Israel, that we will stand with them.

This morning, I joined CNBC’s “Squawk Box” to discuss ongoing investigations into the recent large-scale Russian hack. I highlighted the need to raise the costs for adversaries employing cyber warfare against the U.S., and the need to give the American people more transparency on cyber-attacks so that we understand the gravity of the threat and the strategy being employed to protect our interests.

It’s not every day that I get to have another Marine Corps infantry officer in my office discussing national security issues. General James “Mad Dog” Mattis, President elect Trump’s designee to be our next Defense Secretary, and I discussed a wide array of issues important to Alaska and our nation’s defense including Alaska’s strategic location, a robust missile defense, the critical role of the F-35, the need for deeper engagement in the Arctic and Asia-Pacific, and the importance of having a strong network of allies. I look forward to General Mattis’s swift confirmation so that he may begin his work restoring the focus of our nation’s military on its primary mission – to close with and destroy the enemy.

Wilbur Ross, President-elect Trump’s nominee for Commerce Secretary, joined me for a productive discussion about the importance of Alaska’s fisheries to our state and national economy. I was very impressed with Mr. Ross’s knowledge on a variety of issues – trade, infrastructure, permitting reform and energy production – as well as his business experience in our state. Alaska is the superpower of seafood thanks to science-based management and hard-working Alaska fishermen. As a member of the Senate Commerce Committee, I will work with incoming Secretary Ross to make sure it stays that way.

Director of National Intelligence James Clapper and other officials testified before the Senate Armed Services Committee on last year’s Russian cyber-attack. I hope Director Clapper’s report is made public to the fullest extent possible so that the American people can judge for themselves what really happened without the taint of innuendo or politicized leaks.

The process of electing a new President and Vice President – which was completed today in a ceremony overseen by Vice President Biden – is nearly as old as our nation, having been established in the Constitution’s Twelfth Amendment, ratified in 1804. It was fascinating to witness a sealed letter from each state being opened and read aloud before all members of Congress. Per the Constitution, these letters originate in ceremonies held by electors in each state, which Alaskans saw in Juneau in early December. A few of the Senate pages had the honor of carrying out the envelopes and letter openers – true pieces of history.
Wishing two Alaska legends, Urban Rahoi, of Fairbanks and George Brown, of Anchorage - both veteran pilots of World War II - a very Happy Birthday!

For decades, Alaskans of all political stripes have been pleading with the federal government to let us responsibly develop our resources, including the small, non-wilderness 1002 area of ANWR. This week, Senator Lisa Murkowski and I introduced legislation that would allow development on a mere 2,000 acres - the equivalent of just 0.01% of a refuge that is about the same size as the state of South Carolina - that the USGS estimates is America's largest untapped onshore oil prospect. I’ll do everything I can in this next Congress to work with my colleagues and the new administration to move forward this important prospect that would boost our state and national economies, and provide thousands of good-paying jobs, and billions of dollars in federal and state revenue.

I’ve long been impressed by Oklahoma Attorney General Scott Pruitt’s legal analysis & incisive refutation of the lawless overreach seen from President Obama’s EPA these past 8 years. AG Pruitt, President-elect Trump’s nominee to head up the agency, has a clear vision of returning the EPA to its role of reasonably implementing laws that protect the environment without needlessly stifling jobs and economic opportunity. We will take up his nomination soon in the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee.

I joined Eric Shawn on Fox News to discuss the recently released report by America’s intelligence agencies on the 2016 Russian hack. Although the report provides no evidence that Russian hacking swayed the November election, the attack reveals the need for a comprehensive strategy to counter threats and raise the costs on nations, like China, Russia and Iran, and non-state actors carrying out attacks.

Today on the Senate floor, I had the honor of recognizing my first “Alaskan of the Week” – the talented Tlingit writer Ernestine Hayes, of Juneau, who is also Alaska’s 2017 Writer Laureate. The stories of Alaskans doing good work all across the state should be told. That’s why it was so appropriate for the kickoff to recognize a storyteller. Thanks to Professor Hayes for all you do and thanks to the many Alaskans across our state who work for all of us to strengthen our communities.

It is a sad reality that on National Law Enforcement Appreciation Day, we learn of two more brave police officers who were killed in the line of duty, this time in Florida. In many cases, our officers are being targeted, and it is a disgrace. This Congress, I will reintroduce and work with my colleagues to pass the Protect Our Heroes Act, which would make it a federal offense to assault or kill a police officer, with an enhanced penalty for offenders who lure officers to a location to harm them. I want our law enforcement officers to know that we have their back, and that we deeply appreciate the work they do to keep us safe, and the sacrifices made by them and their families.

One of the principal accomplishments of the Commerce Committee in the last Congress was the NOAA Sexual Harassment & Assault Prevention Act, which I sponsored with Senator Schatz of Hawaii. The bill protects the rights of NOAA employees, who often work prolonged missions at sea, and directs the agency to put in place a clear policy on sexual misconduct, including the necessary reporting mechanisms and protections for employees against retaliation. Take a look at some of the other accomplishments of this bipartisan committee: https://sen.gov/P4Z4

The House last week passed the REINS (Regulations from the Executive in Need of Scrutiny) Act, a major step toward regaining control of the federal regulatory state. The Act, which requires regs involving an annual compliance cost of $100 million or more to be reviewed by the people’s representatives, comes in response to eight years of an Administration that has often been legislating through regulation. Along with the REINS Act, I will be working with my colleagues in the coming months on an agenda to rein in out-of-control federal agencies, create an environment for our job creators to grow and hire again, and restore respect for the Constitution’s separation of powers.

I had a productive meeting with Vincent Viola, President elect Trump’s designee as Secretary of the Army. We spent considerable time talking about the importance of Alaska’s strategically positioned Army forces, including the 1-25 Stryker Brigade in the Interior and the 4-25 Airborne Infantry Brigade Combat Team at JBER. I was pleased to hear that Mr. Viola and I share the view that our Army force structure is much too small. I look forward to working with the incoming secretary to not only increase the size of our Army, but also to improve the readiness of our ground forces.

Alaska veterans lost a dear member of the community and an outstanding veteran volunteer with the passing of Ms. Josephine “Jo” Ke-A. For 19 years, Jo faithfully served vets free coffee in the primary care unit hallway at the Anchorage VA Clinic. A picture has since been placed on the cart in her honor. Her warm greetings and hot coffee impacted every veteran she met and will be sorely missed. For those able to attend, her service will be held at the Ft. Richardson National Cemetery this Friday at 10am. I would like to extend my warmest regards and sympathy to her family. They can be very proud of all the lives she's touched in her decades of volunteer service.

Early this morning, the Senate took the first major step toward repealing the Affordable Care Act, keeping our promise to the American people. In 2009, President Obama and those who supported Obamacare told us, “‘If you like your health care plan, you can keep it. If you like your doctor, you can keep your doctor.” That has not proven to be true for millions across our country – and Alaska is ground zero. With skyrocketing premiums and deductibles and one provider left on the exchange, our healthcare system is in a downward spiral. The Affordable Care Act is not affordable for thousands of Alaskans. Doing nothing was not an option. In this new Congress, I am committed to working with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle on an orderly transition that focuses on market-oriented reforms that reduce the cost of healthcare without growing the size of government, and ultimately provides greater healthcare affordability and choice for Alaskans.

Today, I joined 80 of my colleagues in voting for a waiver enabling retired General James Mattis to serve as our next Secretary of Defense. General Mattis is uniquely qualified to serve, understands and respects our Constitution, and has the admiration and support of our men and women in uniform, and the American people. I also had the opportunity today to ask General Mattis, in his confirmation hearing, about America’s response to China’s militarization of the South China Sea, Russia’s unprecedented build-up in the Arctic, and other challenges he may face as the incoming secretary.

Dr. David Shulkin, who currently serves as VA Undersecretary of Health, has been nominated by President-elect Trump to be the next VA Secretary. In 2015, at my invitation, Dr. Shulkin visited Alaska to hear from Alaska veterans, and understand the barriers and unique challenges of our state. I look forward to building on the working relationship Dr. Shulkin and I have had since his confirmation. There is still much work to be done. Alaska veterans should know that I will continue to hold the VA's feet to fire until each and every Alaska veteran gets the healthcare they were promised and deserve.

I was deeply saddened to hear about the passing of Kaladi Brothers CFO Dale Tran, an active and beloved member of the Alaska community. Dale had an incredible life story having fled with his family from Vietnam in 1974 at the height of the war. He was committed to giving back to the country that welcomed his family, serving in the Washington Army National Guard until 1996, when he came to Alaska. Dale was generous and kind, a tireless fundraiser for local charitable causes and a mentor to many young Alaskans at UAA. He was a person with a “zest for helping others” – something my staff members and I can attest to. Julie and I extend our condolences to Dale’s wife, Joy, and their daughters.

More positive news for our state: ConocoPhillips announced today that it had discovered a field in NPR-A that could produce up to 100,000 barrels a day! This follows two recent announcements of big finds on the North Slope by independent companies Armstrong Oil & Gas and Caelus Energy. Working with Senator Murkowski, Congressman Young and the incoming Trump Administration, we'll do all we can do on the federal level to ensure these fields produce for Alaska. Today's announcement is another reminder that we have tremendous resources in our state and we have an incredibly bright future if we all work together to realize our potential.

This week I received the commitment of Elaine Chao, President-elect Trump’s nominee to lead the Transportation Department, to come to Alaska and see the unique challenges and opportunities we have when it comes to infrastructure. Ms. Chao also committed to working with me on significant federal regulatory reforms so that any new major infrastructure investment does not waste taxpayer dollars and delivers projects in a timely and cost-effective manner.

I chatted with Hugh Hewitt this week regarding the upcoming confirmation hearings that I will be participating in on Capitol Hill, as well as the economic and foreign policy challenges facing the new administration. Take a listen.

In this new Congress, I will assume the chairmanship of the Senate Commerce Subcommittee on Oceans, Atmosphere, Fisheries, and Coast Guard. This committee is particularly important to Alaska, the largest producer and exporter of seafood in the nation, home to the largest Coast Guard base in the nation, and home to more ocean coastline than the rest of the United States combined. I look forward to continuing the bipartisan work of the committee, with particular focus on strengthening our Coast Guard, addressing the threat of marine debris to our coastal communities and ecosystems, and ensuring Alaska’s fisheries thrive for generations to come.

Alaska has lost a great pioneer in rural healthcare with the passing of H. Sally Smith, an advocate who worked tirelessly for more than four decades to advance the health and well-being of Alaska Natives and Native Americans. Sally had a distinguished career, serving as chairman of the Bristol Bay Area Health Corp. Board, chairman of the National Indian Health Board, and vice chairman of the Alaska Native Tribal Health Consortium, among many other posts. As KDLG reports, Sally's friends and colleagues remember her as a humble, well-respected leader who did not seek credit for her accomplishments. Julie and I extend our prayers and condolences to Sally's family during this difficult time.

Today we remember Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.— a man of courage and conviction, a true American hero. Against tremendous odds, his campaign for peaceful change, for human dignity and for justice for all made us a better and stronger nation. His words and actions have stayed with us and ring strong across our nation—from the coasts to the heartland, from the Deep South to the Far North. His memorable words from one of the most important speeches in American history should never be forgotten; “I have a dream that my four little children will one day live in a nation where they will not be judged by the color of their skin but by the content of their character.” Happy Martin Luther King, Jr. Day, Alaska. We all need to work together to continue to realize Dr. King’s dream.

On Monday, around 300 Marines landed in Norway, where they will be based for the first time since World War II. The Arctic training they will undertake with our Norwegian allies is needed, given Russia’s rapid militarization of its High North. Given the growing importance of the Arctic to international trade and resource development, our military needs to regain its decisive proficiency in operating in harsh Arctic environments. By focusing on training opportunities in the Arctic, these U.S. Marines—along with their expert counterparts at U.S. Army Alaska—are leading the way.

I joined Arthel Neville on Fox News this weekend to discuss the process for reviewing President-elect Trump’s cabinet nominees, including General Mattis to lead the Defense Department and Oklahoma Attorney General Scott Pruitt to lead the EPA. Take a listen.

In recent weeks, we’ve seen stern condemnations and tough talk from President Obama regarding cyber-attacks against America and our intelligence community. Those words ring hollow today as President Obama commutes the sentence of Private Manning who, as a member of the U.S. military, was found responsible for leaking hundreds of thousands of classified U.S. diplomatic cables and U.S. Army reports. This massive leak endangered the lives of our men and women in uniform, other Americans – some under cover – as well as the lives of allies all across the globe. This outrageous commutation, which releases Private Manning in just a few months, is a slap in the face to our service members who do the right thing day in and day out, serving our country with honor. Some are calling Private Manning a hero. I know real heroes – some of whom, unlike Private Manning, did not return from Iraq and Afghanistan.

Outgoing Secretary of the Army Eric Fanning presented me with the Decoration for Distinguished Civilian Service Award, a huge honor given to a few members of Congress who have contributed to the accomplishment of the Army’s missions. Secretary Fanning is a friend of Alaska who understands our state’s strategic location, our world-class training opportunities, and our military-friendly communities. It has been a privilege to work alongside Secretary Fanning and Army Chief of Staff General Mark Milley to ensure the Army has the resources it needs to meet the broad array of global threats.

We had a great confirmation hearing today for Commerce Secretary designee Wilbur Ross. I was able to ask Mr. Ross about a number of important issues, including ensuring Alaska’s world-class fisheries continue to thrive and reach global markets, fixing the onerous federal regulatory system that wastes taxpayer dollars on delays and endless reviews, and changing course with the Obama administration’s “new dismal” (not “new normal”) levels of economic growth. I came away with confidence that Mr. Ross will fight to get our economy growing again, creating good-paying jobs for Alaskans and all Americans.

Oklahoma Attorney General Pruitt, President elect Trump's nominee to lead the EPA, spent hours today answering tough questions with ease and intelligence. He made it clear that he will uphold the rule of law, and work with Alaska to protect our environment and be a partner in progress, rather than an impediment to economic growth. AG Pruitt also committed to working with Alaskans to build much-needed water and wastewater infrastructure in our rural communities, and lifting some overreaching and burdensome federal environmental requirements, including for our fishermen. I look forward to working with Mr. Pruitt in the years ahead to regain some of the trust that Alaskans have lost in the EPA.

I had a productive and insightful discussion with President-elect Trump's Secretary of State designee Rex Tillerson. He understands the importance of America’s global allies and the need to restore their trust and confidence, which has waned in recent years. Mr. Tillerson affirmed the role energy can play as an instrument of American power and diplomacy, and recognized that Alaska and our abundant, untapped resources are a key to American energy and national security. The Arctic, in particular, needs to be seen not through a single lens, but as a frontier of great strategic importance, and economic and energy opportunity where America can and should be leading. Mr. Tillerson clearly understands this, and I look forward to his swift confirmation.

I had the honor of joining Senator Murkowski and Congressman Young in welcoming Alaskans to D.C. for the inauguration. This is an exciting time for our country, and I'm glad so many are here to experience it together.
Celebrating this historic moment of inaugurating our new President with a bipartisan group of friends and colleagues.

I was proud to cast my first vote under the new administration for General James Mattis to be our Secretary of Defense. General Mattis is a man of great conviction, courage and honor, and I'm confident that he'll make an exemplary leader for our military. Semper Fi.

Today we witnessed the peaceful transfer of power in America, one of the great hallmarks of our country’s democracy. For over 200 years, this transfer of authority has demonstrated to the rest world that in the United States, the voters choose their leaders, and the Constitution—not one person nor one political party—reigns supreme. Today, President Trump told us that he will take action to move the country forward, creating economic opportunity, building a strong national defense, and working to strengthen relationships with our existing allies while reaching out to create new ones. He also emphasized something that too many in Washington, DC have forgotten: that our government was established to serve the people, not the other way around.   Demonstrating their patriotism and love of country, hundreds of Alaskans flew to DC for the inauguration. I had the honor of spending much of yesterday with many of them. Like all of them, I want to congratulate President Trump, Vice President Pence and their families on this historic day. Now let's get work!

I’d like to commend the Alaska Guardsmen whose mission brought them to the forefront of American democracy this past weekend. Forty-seven Guardsmen departed Anchorage for Washington, DC on an Alaska Air National Guard 168th Wing KC-135 Stratotanker. While temporarily deployed to our nation’s capital, they supported security operations for the presidential inauguration. Hats off to these great Alaskans for doing an exemplary job representing our state.

I'm live this morning at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington to discuss the vital importance of the Arctic and to preview the Department of Defense's new Arctic Strategy before its official release.

I had the honor of recognizing Eileen Dubowski, of Salcha, on the Senate Floor this afternoon as my Alaskan of the Week. Eileen has served as a regular and special education teacher for 40 years, most recently at University Park Elementary. She has a passion for her work, going so far as to take night classes to learn American Sign Language to better communicate with her students. Eileen, also a very active wrestling coach, was recently elected into the Alaska Wrestling Hall of Fame. Congratulations, Eileen, and thank you for serving as such a great role model for our young people.

I applaud President Trump for reviving the Keystone XL Pipeline, a major resource project for our country that the Obama administration had stopped in its tracks—much like some wanted to do decades ago to the Trans-Alaska Pipeline. Responsible resource development means good-paying jobs to support families, and a lot of revenue for state and federal governments. I’m grateful we now have an administration that recognizes more American energy is good, and is taking action on behalf of our workers and families.

Andrew Kurka, one of Alaska’s many world-class athletes, took home his first World Championship as a Paralympic skier today in Italy. At age 13, Andrew sustained a spinal cord injury, but he never let that hold him back from pursuing his love of sports, including, as ADN’s Beth Bragg reports, “bodybuilding, water-skiing, ultra-marathon handcycling, even the harrowing, high-speed Arctic Man ski-and-snowmachine race.” Congratulations, Andrew, and thank you for representing Alaska so well!

President Trump today visited the Department of Homeland Security with the new secretary, retired General John Kelly. I met with General Kelly prior to his confirmation where we discussed the strategic importance of icebreakers in the Arctic, implementing a more robust border security policy, and combating the opioid epidemic. A 45-year veteran of the U.S. Marine Corps and a former commander of U.S. Southern Command, General Kelly has the relevant experience and well understands the strategy required to tackle organized crime, terrorist organizations and drug trafficking.

Next Wednesday, February 1, I will have the opportunity to question Dr. David Shulkin, President Trump’s VA Secretary Designee. It is an honor to represent Alaska veterans, and I want to incorporate your questions and concerns into the confirmation hearing. My time is limited, so I can only ask a few, but your perspective will be heard and taken into account moving forward with the new VA Secretary. Please send them by Monday, January 30 to hearing_questions@sullivan.senate.gov. I look forward to hearing from you, and thank you for your service!

Today I was proud to March for Life with tens of thousands of Americans from all across the country. All of us joined this peaceful demonstration to affirm our belief that life is precious and we need to protect the most vulnerable. #MarchforLife2017
Alaska's own snow-machine champ Cory Davis competes today in his 11th X Games in Aspen. Wishing Cory a great competition, and hoping he adds to his 6 medals!

There has been a significant amount of confusion and misinformation about the recent actions the Trump administration took regarding its executive order that had as its goal to better protect our country. With time to review and analyze the actual order, we have greater clarity and I am heartened to see that the order itself does not reflect some of the misguided rhetoric used during the campaign. As I noted during that time – while we must aggressively fight against radical Islam, we cannot sacrifice our country's founding principles.  The public should know that those immigrants who hold a green card and are lawful permanent residents are not affected. The public should also know that this order does not target those who practice a specific religion.  Rather, it is about temporarily suspending visitors and those seeking refugee status to the United States predominantly from countries that the former Obama administration and now Trump administration deem a security risk to our country. The temporary restrictions, which I support, will be in place until our vetting and screening system is thoroughly reexamined to ensure terrorists aren’t entering our country. Witnesses testified before the Homeland Security Committees last Congress that screening procedures needed to be reviewed.  As we move forward, I would hope that the Trump Administration better communicates the facts to agency officials, Congress, the American people, and our allies abroad. It is important to remember that some of our most critical allies in the war on terrorism are majority Muslim countries. Additionally, it’s important that those foreign nationals who have served with our U.S. military abroad – in countries like Iraq – be given special consideration when examining their immigration and refugee eligibility.   I would also hope that Senate Democrats cease their unprecedented obstruction of cabinet officials, so that agencies can be fully staffed and prepared for such orders.     Lastly, my office stands ready to assist constituents and their families who have been affected by this order.

I applaud President Trump today for issuing an executive order mandating federal agencies to cut two regulations for each new reg promulgated – similar to the RED Tape Act I have proposed since 2015. Many economists and experts across the country point to regulations—the size and scope of which continue to increase substantially year after year—as a major factor in our sluggish economy. If it were a country, U.S. regulations would rank as the world’s 10th largest economy, behind Russia and ahead of India. The order today is a bold step toward fixing the problem of overregulation. To strengthen the order, I hope that my colleagues in Congress will join me in an open and transparent debate about our regulatory and permitting regime, and consider passing the RED Tape Act.

Today my staff and I surprised Vietnam Veteran Will Lee, from the Mat-Su, with a Bronze Star that he earned but never received. My exceptional staffers, Josh and Margaret, got to work on his case and were able to obtain the medal along with an entire set of service medals Will earned. If you are a veteran trying to receive the awards you have earned, or an Alaskan having difficulties with a federal agency, please know that we are here to help. While we can’t always guarantee a positive outcome, I can promise we will work hard on your behalf. Congratulations, Will, and thank you for your service to our country!

President Trump, in nominating Judge Neil Gorsuch, has selected a highly credentialed jurist with the temperament and distinguished career fitting of a justice of the U.S. Supreme Court. Confirmed by the U.S. Senate on a voice vote to the 10th Circuit Court of Appeals in 2006, Judge Gorsuch is well within the mainstream of American judicial philosophy and has demonstrated the judgment necessary to garner the support of Republicans and Democrats alike. Judge Gorsuch’s record reflects Justice Scalia’s legacy of textualism and an ardent respect for the Constitution and rule of law. He is poised to make an excellent addition to the Supreme Court.

Senate Democrats boycotted an Environment & Public Works Committee vote on Oklahoma Attorney General Scott Pruitt to lead the EPA, meandering in the hallway so that members could not consider the nomination. Their calls for greater scrutiny and time ring hollow – AG Pruitt has answered more than 1,000 more questions than any other EPA nominee in recent history. These kinds of temper tantrums waste a lot of time and energy, and do not serve the American people. Let’s get to work.

While I share many of the concerns of Senator Murkowski, after meeting with President Trump's Education Secretary nominee, Betsy DeVos, she committed to me that she will work with all Alaskans to strengthen education throughout the state, in both public and private schools. She committed to implementing the Every Student Succeeds Act as Congress intended it, without implementing regulations that place the power into the hands of the Department of Education, and supports accountability for all schools as determined by the states.  Mrs. DeVos also committed to supporting funding for the Alaska Native Equity Program, and agreed to help identify opportunities at the Department of Education for digital learning to be brought to Alaskans. After discussing the unique challenges many Alaskans face in receiving an education, she committed to visiting Alaska and working with us to formulate best practices that work for our most remote schools.  Most importantly, she is someone who cares deeply about our kids. She committed to working closely with states and local school districts – which are closest to our students – and return the decision-making process back to where it belongs: with local school administrators, teachers, and parents to ensure that our most vulnerable populations receive access to a high-quality education, especially in rural Alaska.

I voted today to overturn the Obama administration's job-killing stream buffer zone regulation that was issued without meaningfully consulting with states during the rule-making process. This rule created a blanket national regulation that seriously limits the availability of abundant and affordable resources to power the lights and heat our homes in Interior Alaska and other regions across the country. Going forward, we must work together to reduce and modernize regulatory requirements, not create a maze of duplicative, conflicting, and industry killing regulations.

My D.C. and Alaska offices are receiving a high volume of calls from non-Alaskans weighing in on President Trump's cabinet nominees. Alaskans – if you are having trouble getting through, please know that you can still reach me via my website at sullivan.senate.gov/contact. My staff and I do receive and review your messages there, and appreciate hearing from you.

This week I received the commitment of Dr. David Shulkin, President Trump’s nominee for VA secretary, to address the deficiencies of the Choice Program in Alaska, to ensure our community-based scheduling continues on track, and to again visit Alaska—this time our rural communities. It is imperative that the VA restores the confidence and trust it has lost over the years among veterans. Dr. Shulkin committed that if he is unable to regain that trust and improve the system, he should be held accountable and replaced. I couldn’t agree more.

I applaud the Trump administration’s announcement of new sanctions against Iran following the recent ballistic missile test. Since the signing of the Iran Nuclear Deal, the regime has been intent on undermining the agreement at every turn, and yet none of the P5+1 countries – including the U.S. under the Obama administration – have called Iran out on these and other violations of UN Security Council Resolution 2231 and the JCPOA. I penned an op-ed in the Washington Post arguing that a better way forward than disavowing the deal is to let it fail on its own – by vigorously enforcing it.

I was honored to recognize World Champion Paralympic skier Andrew Kurka, of Palmer, recently as my Alaskan of the Week. Andrew's perseverance and athletic accomplishments are amazing enough, but his willingness to serve as a role model for others is what makes him a true Alaska treasure. Congratulations, Andrew, from all of your supporters. You are a great inspiration to all of us.

Nominating exceptional young Alaskans to our nation’s Military Service Academies is such a privilege, and this year was no different. All of the nominees exhibited the characteristics that will help them to succeed as leaders in our nation’s military: academic excellence, demonstrated leadership, and a commitment to serving their community and nation. I am so impressed with these future leaders, and I want to congratulate each of them on their nomination.

After nearly two years of advocacy and bipartisan efforts, I am pleased the Department of Defense released a serious military strategy for the Arctic. While it is not perfect, the strategy is a dramatic improvement from the 2013 version which was more platitudes and pictures than actual substance. I am hopeful that the entire DoD, our new President, and the country will take a serious look at this document and begin to formulate how our country will safeguard our interests, and that of our allies, in this strategically-important region. We are an Arctic nation and with this important strategy, we are starting to act like one.

Today I voted for Betsy DeVos to be the next Secretary of Education. During my meeting with her, I was satisfied that Ms. DeVos truly cares about the education of all of Alaska’s children – both in our rural and our urban areas – and, like me, fundamentally believes that education decisions are best left in the hands of state and local authorities, and that parental involvement is critical. As I said when I announced my support for Ms. DeVos, I received a number of commitments from her about education in Alaska as well as her full commitment to enforce the Every Student Succeeds Act, which passed the Senate overwhelmingly – with the strong support of Alaska’s teachers – and was signed into law in 2015. In the months ahead, I look forward to working with Secretary DeVos as she fulfills these commitments, and to having her come to Alaska, see our schools, meet with our teachers and students, and work to find sustainable solutions that provide high-quality education for all Alaskans.

America’s alliances are one of the most important strategic advantages that the United States has at hand. We are ally rich, and our enemies or potential adversaries are ally poor. One of those crucial longstanding alliances is with Japan, whose Prime Minister visits the U.S. later this week. I look forward to meeting with Prime Minister Abe and ensuring the strong cooperation and partnership between our two nations continues for years to come.

The bounty of Alaska’s world-class fisheries was on display today at the U.S. Department of Agriculture. The Alaska Seafood Marketing Institute hosted an event demonstrating the nutritional value of fresh Alaskan Pollock, which is healthier than fish from farms or foreign markets. Commercial fishing is integral to Alaska’s economy, and I look forward to using my chairmanship of the Senate Commerce Subcommittee on Oceans, Atmosphere, Fisheries & Coast Guard to ensure our fisheries remain the best managed in the world.

I was pleased to vote for Senator Jeff Sessions today to be our next U.S. Attorney General. Senator Sessions is an outstanding public servant who has worked tirelessly for decades for his constituents in Alabama and for all Americans across the country. Senator Sessions’ colleagues know him as a man of integrity and principle. I am confident that he will uphold the laws of the land and will be a fierce advocate for the rule of law and defending our Constitution. I look forward to working with him in reestablishing constitutional principles that have deteriorated under the former Administration.

Congratulations to Zach Barnes, Sarah Montalbano, Lucas Arthur, Charles Michael and Jacob Cucinello of Mat-Su Career Tech on winning this year’s state Science Bowl. As Matt Hickman writes in the Frontiersman, several members of this team took home the title last year competing as the school’s “B-Team” – an impressive feat. The bowl quizzes teams on topics including “biology, chemistry, math, energy, astronomy, physics and general science.” I think this is a fantastic way to get students excited about the sciences, and better prepared for higher education and good-paying careers. Best of luck at Nationals!

I was honored to once again meet with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, a once-in-a-generation leader who is leading his country into a safer and more prosperous Asia-Pacific. We had a constructive conversation today about deepening the military, economic, trade, and energy relationship between our two countries. I highlighted Alaska’s longstanding role as a reliable supplier of LNG to Japan for over 40 years. I look forward to working with him and his administration on strengthening U.S. military, economic and energy ties that benefit both of our nations, and Alaska.

Today on the Senate floor, I recognized AlexAnna Salmon, of Igiugig, as the “Alaskan of the Week.” AlexAnna is a leader and advocate who is pioneering new efforts to better her community and ensure access to a sustainable supply of food and energy. Her dedication epitomizes what it means to be an Alaskan, honoring the traditions of our past and seizing the opportunities here and now to provide for a bright future.

Yesterday’s missile test by North Korea - and the two recent tests by Iran - are just the latest reasons why the U.S. needs to invest in a much stronger missile defense system. Both of these rogue nations aspire to have nuclear weapons that they can use to threaten American cities. When, not if, the unstable leaders of North Korea and Iran get this capability, the American people will need to know that the Congress saw this coming and that we have a robust missile defense system that will keep us safe and serve as a vital insurance policy against nuclear threats from rogue nations. The costs and benefits of a comprehensive missile defense system demand action now. I look forward to working with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle, as well as the Trump administration, on this important issue.

Thank you to the volunteers who gathered recently at MYHouse in Wasilla to assemble kits of naloxone, essential to reversing a heroin or opioid overdose. Having these kits widely available in Alaska is one critical tool in combatting the state’s opioid epidemic. I want to thank Alaska’s Chief Medical Officer, Dr. Butler, and his team for providing my office with a prototype and briefing on the project. It is particularly heartening to see recovering addicts stepping forward to help Alaskans facing similar struggles with the hope of saving lives. To request an overdose kit, contact ProjectHope@alaska.gov.

I was honored to speak to members of the 477th Fighter Squadron and congratulate honorees at their annual awards ceremony over the weekend. The 477th has a rich history of groundbreaking achievement from training the legendary Tuskegee Airmen during WWII to becoming the first Air Force Reserve unit to fly, maintain and support the F-22 Raptor. The 477th continues to build on its noteworthy legacy through many successful missions across the globe. These Alaska Airmen are remarkable young men and women, and I wish them all the best in their careers ahead.

Congratulations to Matt Hall, of Two Rivers, and his team from “Smokin’ Ace Kennels” on winning the challenging 1,000-mile-long Yukon Quest Sled Dog Race. Matt has risen through the ranks in recent years, finishing fourth in 2016 and third in 2014, according to the Newsminer. It has been a tough race so far with six of the 21 original teams having dropped. Safe travels to the mushers still on their way to Fairbanks!

I want to thank Governor Walker and Commissioner Davidson for their state disaster declaration, which will put significant resources forward to combat the opioid epidemic harming too many families and communities across Alaska. All stakeholders – federal, state, local – must work together to advance efforts for prevention, emergency response, and treatment as well as reduce the stigma attached to addiction. I look forward to working with the Overdose Response Program and the many other programs and associations throughout the state combatting addiction of any kind.

Today we honor and remember Elizabeth Peratrovich, a crucial leader in the fight for equal rights for Alaska Natives at a time when they experienced harsh discrimination. Her advocacy was instrumental in the Alaska Territorial Legislature’s passage of the Anti-Discriminination Act of 1945, making Alaska the first place in the United States to outlaw racial segregation. Alaska is a much better place today thanks to the courage and example of Elizabeth Peratrovich.

I voted today to confirm Oklahoma Attorney General Scott Pruitt as the next administrator of the EPA. He understands that the EPA needs a serious course correction – that it must get back to listening to the states and respecting the rule of law, and most importantly, regaining the trust of the American people. He has committed to administering the environmental protection laws passed by Congress faithfully, without acting as an impediment to economic growth and opportunity for our citizens. I look forward to working with him in his new role to protect Alaska’s clean air and water, and the interests of everyone in our state.

I had the honor of recognizing Mona Painter, an integral member of the Cooper Landing community for six decades. Congratulations, Mona, and thank you and for your work to support your neighbors and preserve the area's history for future generations.
Good luck to all of the Iron Dog racers making the 2,000-mile trek to Nome and Fairbanks!

I am very encouraged by President Trump’s selection of Lt. General H.R. McMaster as National Security Adviser. I’ve known Lt. Gen. McMaster for many years, including having served under him as a Marine Corps Major when he was in charge of the Joint Strategic Assessment Team at U.S. Central Command in 2009. He is an innovative and strategic thinker and operator. He clearly understands the importance of bringing all instruments of American power – military, economic, diplomatic, energy and private sector – to bear on our national security challenges. That kind of experience and knowledge will be critical in his role as President Trump’s National Security Adviser.

I had the opportunity in Anchorage to attend a screening of “Glory Denied,” an opera version of the story of Colonel Jim Thompson, a Vietnam Veteran and the longest-held prisoner of war in U.S. history. The opera recounts the challenges faced by Colonel Thompson as he returned home, trying to return to a normal life. I want to thank Senator John McCain, another American hero and former prisoner of war, for sharing a video message with attendees. Colonel Thompson’s experience is an important reminder of the sacrifices that have been made for our freedoms, and the support still needed by many of our service members recovering from the wounds of war. I'd also like to thank everyone involved in producing this tribute to honor the legacy of Colonel Thompson.

Despite claims to the contrary, China is continuing to change the facts on the ground in the South China Sea. Building two dozen structures designed to house surface-to-air missiles clearly violates China’s previous promises not to militarize this vital region, where $5.3 trillion of trade – $1.2 trillion of it from the U.S. – passes each year. The U.S. military should continue to fly, sail and operate in the South China Sea, and everywhere else international law allows. China’s attempts to restrict access to this critical region should not be tolerated by the U.S. or our allies.

Congratulations to our 2017 Alaska Military Service Members of the Year! These outstanding enlisted men and women have worked very hard to earn this coveted title, exhibiting excellence in their work and setting a high standard for their peers. They make us all proud. I'd also like to thank the Armed Services YMCA of Alaska for hosting the Annual Salute to the Military for 40 years, and for all of the amazing programs and services they offer our military members and their families.

I had a great tour of ABLE Locksmiths & Security Center in Anchorage with the owner, Clint Waggoner, and his employees. ABLE is a mom and pop small business that has been part of the Anchorage community for 50 years. Clint worked his way up and had the opportunity to purchase the business. He is hoping to hire more Alaskans to his current staff of 15-20 employees if Congress and the new administration are able to lift the tax and regulatory burdens facing his business. I say, it’s time we get it done!

My staff attended a great "Meet the World" event today at the Dena'ina Center hosted by Bridge Builders. The organization does great work building a community of friends from all cultures, so many of which are represented in Alaska. Thank you to the many Alaskans participating, and to the talented dancers and performers who shared their traditions with everyone.

One hundred years ago today, Charles Sheldon, who, with the help of the Boone and Crockett Club, had relentlessly lobbied Congress, saw his dream turn into reality: President Woodrow Wilson established what’s now called the Denali National Park and Preserve. Denali is undoubtedly one of the most treasured parts of our national park system, having provided countless hours of awe and tranquility for Alaskans and for all Americans. Happy Birthday, Denali!

Alaska has so many talented photographers, amateur and professional alike. I want to invite you again to share your best shots of Alaska’s landscapes, wildlife and outdoor fun. Submit your work for our winter Frontier in Focus photo contest to photos@sullivan.senate.gov by Friday, March 10. We’ll pick our five favorites for Alaskans to vote on right here on Facebook. Once we have a winner, I’ll display their work in my office with the skilled photographer’s name for all of our visitors to see. Good luck!

Alaska vets – tomorrow, February 28, at 10:00am and 5:30pm, the Alaska VA is hosting a Vocational Rehabilitation & Employment Participant Engagement Session at the VA Medical Center in Anchorage. The VA is looking for your ideas and recommendations as they work to improve the experience for VR&E participants. As always, we will keep you updated on other upcoming opportunities to engage with the VA around the state as they come up.

I was proud to cast my vote today to confirm Wilbur Ross as the next Secretary of Commerce. In meetings with Mr. Ross, and through his confirmation process, I have been impressed with his knowledge of many issues important to Alaska – including trade, infrastructure and the need to reform our regulatory system – as well as his own business experience in our state. I look forward to working with Secretary Ross on growing job opportunities for Alaskans and ensuring Alaska’s fisheries remain the strongest and best-managed of any in the world.

I'm sickened by the recent destruction of Jewish cemeteries this week and of the bomb threats against Jewish community centers and schools, including in Anchorage. These attacks and threats are heinous crimes and I expect our authorities to conduct a thorough investigation and to bring the perpetrators to justice. Our thoughts and prayers are with the Lubavitch Jewish Center of Alaska and with all religious institutions across our country that are being threatened.

Today I joined President Trump and several of my colleagues for the signing of a new executive order to review and roll back the expansive overreach in the Waters of the United States (WOTUS) Rule, which gave the EPA vast new authority over lands across the country, particularly in Alaska. This new order signals a return to the rule of law and prioritizes environmental protection, keeping our waters clean without running rough shod over the Clean Water Act and our economy. I look forward to working with my colleagues and EPA Administrator Pruitt to return to a balanced and statutorily based implementation of our environmental laws.
President Donald Trump delivers his first address to a joint session of Congress.
Here are my initial thoughts following President Trump's strong and unifying first address to a joint session of Congress.

Last week, nearly 200 U.S. Army paratroopers of the 4th Infantry Brigade Combat Team (Airborne) - the ONLY airborne brigade in the Arctic and the Pacific - demonstrated their strategic importance by conducting yet another successful airborne operation into a drop zone 200 miles north of the Arctic Circle. These soldiers braved ambient temperatures of -35 degrees Fahrenheit and even endured wind chill temperatures dropping into the negative 60s. And for their "jumpmasters" doing the safety checks leaning outside of the aircraft, it was a face-freezing 100 degrees below zero.  Congratulations to the paratroopers of the entire 4-25 Airborne Brigade!

For Alaska’s interests and future, there is perhaps no more important position in the federal administration than the Secretary of the Interior. Newly confirmed Secretary Ryan Zinke is a trained geologist, a lifelong sportsman, a former Navy SEAL and, most importantly, a patriotic and ethical man. He understands that Alaska’s lands are vital to the well-being of our communities, providing for our livelihood, economic opportunity, and cultures. He also rejects the false choice between protecting our environment and responsibly developing our resources, understanding we can do both. I look forward to working with Secretary Zinke as he restores the department’s role as a partner with the state, respecting the rights and responsibilities granted to Alaska at statehood.

Congratulations to the Alaska Air National Guard’s 212th Rescue Squadron and 249th Airlift Squadron on being named finalists for the prestigious National Aeronautic Association Collier Trophy, awarded annually "for the greatest achievement in aeronautics or astronautics in America.” Past winners include: Chuck Yeager and X-1 designers for achieving supersonic flight, Apollo 11 for the first landing of a man on the moon, and most recently, the Dawn Mission Team for orbiting and exploring Vesta and Ceres. Being nominated is a testament to the Alaska Squadron’s remarkable accomplishment in the local development of long-range search-and rescue-capability and the Arctic Sustainment Package. Best of luck to these brave Airmen!

The Senate today confirmed Dr. Ben Carson as the next Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. Dr. Carson is a man of character with a truly inspiring story of perseverance. In our meeting, Dr. Carson was well-versed in existing HUD programs in Alaska, including the Indian Housing Block Grant and “Moving to Work.” I appreciate Dr. Carson’s holistic approach to government, understanding that social challenges are not siloed into specific agencies. I look forward to working with him to help HUD invest in our individuals and communities.

I am pleased to announce the National Marine Fisheries Service is implementing the necessary regulations to ensure a timely Alaska halibut fishery, set to open on March 11. My staff and I have been working to help resolve this issue for weeks, and the urgency of it was reinforced during my travels in Southeast Alaska last week. Earlier this week I spoke with our new Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross about this issue, and later today I will be speaking with him again to express my thanks on behalf of Alaskan fishermen.   The Trump administration has been clear; they are laser focused on strengthening the economy, and cutting burdensome regulations are a critical part of that effort. But today's news demonstrates that routine measures that empower our fishermen – Alaska's quintessential small businessmen – will proceed as needed so they can continue to deliver a quality product to Americans’ dinner plates, and create the jobs that support our coastal communities.

I joined CNBC’s Squawk Box this morning to discuss Commerce Secretary Ross’s and the broader Trump administration’s sharp focus on reigniting the engine of the American economy. Two major steps toward achieving this goal are reforming our tax code and  reforming the onerous federal regulatory system, which too often have been hurdles to economic opportunity.

I met this week with Judge Neil Gorsuch, President Trump’s nominee to the U.S. Supreme Court. Like the late Justice Antonin Scalia, Judge Gorsuch has a deep respect for upholding the Constitution and faithfully interpreting the law. His emphasis on textualism, federalism, and the separation of powers puts him squarely within the Scalia school of judicial philosophy. Judge Gorsuch has also demonstrated a willingness to challenge federal agencies that step beyond their statutory authority. In this regard, his background as a Westerner will bring much-needed geographic diversity to the Supreme Court. I believe Judge Gorsuch will make an outstanding associate justice, and I look forward to his confirmation in the Senate.
Best wishes to the mushers and dog teams taking part in the 45th Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race! You can keep tabs on the standings, route and trail conditions at:

This week I recognized Joyce McCombs, of Delta Junction, as my Alaskan of the Week. Joyce will soon be celebrating 30 years as the community’s library director, and was also recently honored with the Alaska Library Association’s Audrey P. Kolb Public Library Service Award. Thank you, Joyce, for your efforts to provide a warm, welcoming learning space for Alaskans.

On his first day in office, Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke rescinded a harmful and unnecessary last minute order from the Obama administration that banned traditional ammunition and tackle on U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service land. I want to thank Secretary Zinke for listening to Alaskans and others across the country who were outraged by this ban, and look forward to working with him to manage our lands based on sound science and meaningful consultation.

Veterans and military service members carry many incredible skill sets that are so valuable, but too often go unrecognized by prospective employers. It is important that we work to connect our veterans with good-paying jobs after they leave the service. This week, I heard from members of Veterans Service Organizations, including several Alaskans, about the barriers that exist for veterans trying to make this successful transition to civilian employment.

North Korea is quickly emerging as the most imminent threat to U.S. national security and the global order. My greatest fear is that the American people will, in the near future, wake up to a North Korea that has the ability to fire a nuclear warhead into America’s heartland. When that day comes, we need to ensure that Kim Jong-un knows – without a shred of doubt – that if he launches against our country, not only will he not get through our defenses, but we will massively retaliate. The American people should have confidence in our missile defense system, yet we must continue to modernize and invest in new capabilities. More advanced kill vehicles, new boosters, and additional interceptors are all needed to keep us ahead of this rapidly evolving threat. The time to invest is now.

Veterans and members of our military pick up many incredible skill sets during their service in the armed forces. Unfortunately, when transitioning back into civilian life, their valuable skills sometimes go untapped or unrecognized by prospective employers. This week, I joined Representatives Jeff Denham and Tim Walz, and Senator Joe Manchin, as a Senate co-chair of the Congressional Veterans Jobs Caucus. The caucus is aimed at working with veterans’ service organizations, federal agencies, and private employers to help vets secure jobs and succeed at them. Learn more about the caucus at: https://sen.gov/MXJ9

Senator Murkowski and I had a productive meeting with President Trump and Interior Secretary Zinke today at the White House, discussing everything from a road for King Cove and fisheries, to national security, responsible resource development, and reigniting economic growth in Alaska. We also discussed Alaska’s strategic location and the importance of Alaska’s military forces to our national security. It was a great opportunity for us to explain the challenges facing Alaska, particularly access to our lands, waters, and resources, and to start talking about real solutions. Since the federal government controls more than 60 percent of Alaska’s land, it’s imperative that we move away from the direction of the previous administration – unilateral decisions that locked up our federal areas – and instead partner to increase energy production, mineral development, and timber harvesting. Given the state of our economy and our budget, now is the time to recognize these opportunities and empower Alaskans.

I had a great time meeting with more than 20 bright 4-H students from Palmer on the steps of the Capitol today. They had good questions and have been enjoying the sights of our nation’s capital and learning more about American history and government.

Congratulations to Armstrong Oil & Gas and Repsol on discovering the largest U.S. onshore oil discovery in 30 years – on Alaska’s North Slope. This is big news for Alaska, and it underscores why I remain optimistic about our state’s economic future, in spite of the challenges we face. As Alaska’s former DNR commissioner, we worked closely with the Legislature to enact policies that encouraged additional investment and exploration on the North Slope. These policies are now bearing fruit, and I am optimistic that we are seeing a new renaissance of growth and job creation for Alaskans.
Best wishes and safe travels to Jennifer and Madison as they get ready to compete in the 2017 Special Olympics World Games this weekend in Austria. You make Alaska proud! #Austria2017

For 50 years, Alaska Legal Services Corporation has done vital work offering pro bono representation to some of the most vulnerable in our state. As Alaska’s attorney general, I saw firsthand how important their service is, particularly for victims of domestic violence who had no means to defend themselves, and who were unfamiliar with the legal system. In keeping with its record of serving those in need, ALS is marking its 50-year anniversary by hosting free legal clinics in the coming weeks all across Alaska. Find more details at the link below.

As the son of a Navy veteran, it was a huge honor last night to receive the Association of the U.S. Navy’s National Legislative Advocacy Award, given to two members of Congress each year for supporting the men and women serving in the Navy, and advocating on behalf of the Navy’s many veterans. My dad always likes to remind me that the Marine Corps is a department of the Navy. I was glad to get to share the evening with Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, the other congressional honoree, retired Vice Admiral Lou Crenshaw, and several young sailors proudly serving our country.

The Senate Youth Program is a highly competitive, week-long educational opportunity that brings some of the best and brightest from each of the 50 states to Washington, DC to learn more about our federal government and opportunities to enter public service. Madeline Ko, of Palmer, and Wilfried Zibell, of Noorvik, are Alaska’s stellar representatives, and they were able to meet the President and Vice President, as well as the Supreme Court Chief Justice, among many other incredible visits. Congratulations, Madeline and Wilfried, on this prestigious award, and for your hard work!

This week, I had the opportunity to recognize Glen Hanson, a longtime volunteer with the Iditarod Air Force currently helping out with the 45th Iditarod, as my Alaskan of the Week. Glen has dedicated roughly 1,500 hours of volunteer time – flying veterinarians, the judges, dog handlers and volunteers out to the checkpoints, as well as the supplies, including lumber, dog food and bales of hay. Thank you, Glen, and the entire Iditarod Air Force for helping ensure the Last Great Race continues, and so everyone enjoys a safe journey to Nome.

Here are the five brilliant finalists for our Frontier in Focus winter photo contest! We received a multitude of incredible shots, so don’t be discouraged if your photo was not selected. I appreciate all of the Alaskans who shared their unique perspectives of Alaska. Please note, all images submitted will not be used for any purpose other than this contest, nor without crediting the photographer. Now, I need your help picking a winner! “Like” your favorite, and be sure to share with your Alaskan friends so they can weigh in too. Votes will be tallied at 8pm AKST this Friday, March 17.

Earning the title of U.S. Marine is the proudest personal achievement of my life. Always has been, always will be. As a Marine, a citizen and a lawmaker – I was disgusted by reports of female Marines being attacked and degraded online by fellow Marines. This kind of perversion of Marine culture does not represent the vast majority of Marines I know and have served with, and it has absolutely no place in the Corps – or anywhere else. I appreciate that General Neller has recognized the seriousness of these abuses, takes full responsibility for them, is offering support to female Marines, and is working to bring offenders to account.

For six years going, the Seaveys have led the pack in the Last Great Race, a proud distinction for this revered Alaska family. I’m sure Dallas isn’t excited to see his impressive three-year winning streak and all-time speed record come to an end, but he must be very proud that his dad was the one to do it. Congratulations, Mitch and team, on a record-breaking Iditarod victory! Best wishes to the remaining mushers and teams making their way to Nome.

Last Friday, General “Hawk” Carlisle retired after nearly 39 years of service in the U.S. Air Force. As part of his long and distinguished career, General Carlisle was stationed in Alaska three times! He has long been a persistent advocate for Alaska’s unparalleled training ranges and our strategic location. Thanks to his efforts, Alaska will be an ever-increasing part of the Air Force’s high-end training and power projection. Sincere thanks and congratulations to Hawk for his years of service defending our nation.

Today on the Senate Floor I recognized Pastor Evelyn Erbele, a woman who has dedicated her life to helping others, as the Alaskan of the Week. Evelyn and her husband are co-pastors of Ketchikan’s First United Methodist Church and operate the First City Homeless Services Day Shelter, which provides a hot meal, shower, clean clothes, and a place to be for neighbors who have fallen on hard times. Congratulations, Evelyn, and thank you for upholding the dignity and value of every human being.

Many Alaskans have reached out to me regarding the White House’s FY 2018 Budget Proposal. First and foremost, it’s important to remember that Congress holds the power of the purse, and will ultimately fund the federal government. This budget request from the White House is a first step and a general blueprint for where our country should be headed: Increased funding for our national defense and homeland security, and cuts to agencies that have stifled economic growth over the last eight years. However, some of the specific cuts in this budget disproportionately target rural economies across our country, including in Alaska, and some don’t align with the commitments made by members of the Trump administration during their confirmation process and hearings.   Going forward, I’ll be working closely with Senator Murkowski and Congressman Young to fight for programs and funding specifically designed to help Alaska grow its economy and to build infrastructure projects that align with acceptable modern standards.

Senator Murkowski, Congressman Young and I welcomed a number of students and teachers from IDEA in Homer and Southcentral Foundation in Anchorage, visiting Washington, DC with the Close Up Foundation. We told them they should definitely brag to the other Close Up groups that they got their entire congressional delegation together in one room!

Secretary of State Rex Tillerson is visiting some of our key Asia-Pacific allies this week, all of whom have growing concerns about North Korea’s continued testing of ballistic missiles. Strengthening and modernizing America’s missile defense, including the major assets in Alaska, is crucial to defending the homeland from rogue threats like North Korea. This week, I penned an op-ed detailing five steps that should be taken to keep U.S. missile defense capability ahead of the North Korean threat.

Alaska’s world-class fish and seafood were on display this weekend at the North American Seafood Expo in Boston. I had the opportunity to meet with a number of Alaskans who bring our products, harvested by Alaska fishermen and processors, to markets across the nation and around the globe. As chairman of the Senate Commerce Subcommittee on Oceans, Atmosphere, Fisheries & Coast Guard, I’ll be working to ensure Alaska remains the global superpower of seafood.

One of the most important services my staff provides is helping veterans get the service honors and awards they have earned, but never received. U.S. Army Veteran Ramon Whittaker of Wasilla served in the Vietnam War and later re-enlisted to serve in Panama for Operation Just Cause, and Iraq for Operation Desert Storm. Thanks to the work of my staffer Margaret, we were able to present Ramon with a catalog of more than 14 awards and medals, including the Bronze Star and the Meritorious Service Medal. Thank you Ramon, for your service to our nation.

In honor of World Down Syndrome Day, I donned a pair of funny socks provided by Corbin, a bright young Alaskan from Anchorage. Corbin couldn’t be here, but his mom Karli was in town to meet with me along with the Alaska Governor’s Council on Disabilities and Special Education, which advocates on behalf of the needs of Alaskans with disabilities. Today we are reminded, in the words of Dr. Karen Gaffney, the first person with Down Syndrome to receive an honorary doctorate, that “every life has value, regardless of the amount of chromosomes you have.”

I’m proud to report the Senate today passed House Joint Resolution 69—ushered through the House by Congressman Young in February—overturning an unlawful Obama-era Fish and Wildlife Service rule that restricted Alaska’s ability to manage our resources and undermined public participation. In a blatant example of federal overreach, this regulation clearly usurped Alaska’s legal authority – and could have been used as a precedent in other states. I am thankful that my colleagues recognized that this resolution was backed by the force of law, the principle of federalism, and respect for all Alaskans, many of whom have been hunting, fishing and subsisting off the land for generations.

Judge Neil Gorsuch is undergoing the toughest job interview in the world, and rightfully so considering the importance of the United States Supreme Court. I shared my thoughts today on Judge Gorsuch and how I think his confirmation hearing is going.

The U.S. Coast Guard has a wide range of missions, from search and rescue, icebreaking, and marine environmental protection, to port security, drug interdiction, international crisis response, and readiness to support Department of Defense operations. Today, joined by Commandant Admiral Paul Zukunft, I convened my first hearing as Chairman of the Senate Commerce Subcommittee on Oceans, Atmosphere, Fisheries and the Coast Guard examining the missions, manpower, resources, and acquisitions of the Coast Guard, and its important front-line role in the rapidly changing Arctic region.

Alaska’s Congressional Delegation and staff were on the grounds of the Capitol today for the eighth-annual Choose Respect rally showing support for our fellow Alaskans who have been victims of domestic violence and sexual assault. It was an appropriate day to reintroduce the POWER Act, which would help expand access to pro bono lawyers for victims who too often fear or are unfamiliar with the justice system, or can’t afford a lawyer. I am optimistic with the support of my colleague Senator Heitkamp of North Dakota, and a number of new Senate cosponsors, we can get the POWER Act passed and onto the president’s desk.

General Curtis Scaparrotti, commander of U.S. European Command and the NATO Supreme Allied Commander Europe, testified today before the Senate Armed Services Committee. I brought attention to Russia’s huge military buildup in the Arctic and questioned what our response should be. Acknowledging the strategic importance of this region, he stated, “We clearly need to invest more in the kind of assets that help us in the Arctic…we certainly need to improve our capabilities and I’m concerned…with our capabilities with respect to the High North and Security of the North Atlantic.” We need to invest more in the Arctic and I look forward to supporting General Scaparrotti as he leads the development of these capabilities.

Tomorrow at noon at the Dena’ina Center, there is a great opportunity to hear from the current and former Commanders of the Alaska Command – Lt. General Ken Wilsbach and Retired General Joe Ralston – on the future of the military in Alaska. Hosted by the Alaska World Affairs Council, the event has complimentary tickets available for active duty military and full-time students. Don’t miss it!

I applaud President Trump’s swift action to approve the Keystone XL pipeline. Doing the bidding of extreme special interest groups for eight years, the Obama administration needlessly delayed strengthening our economy and providing American workers with thousands of good-paying jobs. Today, the Trump administration stood up for the hardworking men and women of this country, and sent a message that America understands that a strong economy and North American energy independence strengthen our national security.

Thank you to the many Alaskans who participated in Choose Respect marches and rallies across the state yesterday. All of you give hope to victims and survivors of domestic violence and sexual assault.

This week I had the honor of recognizing Ivory Gerhardt Cyrus, of Kiana, on the Senate floor as the Alaskan of the Week. Ivory is a powerful young advocate for students suffering from fetal alcohol spectrum disorder and also founder of the “One Positive Thing” initiative. Congratulations, Ivory, on all of your accomplishments and best of luck at UAA!

Today we celebrate a great statesman in American history who saw the boundless, untapped potential of the far north frontier of Alaska. Secretary of State William H. Seward weathered a lot of skepticism and ridicule from his contemporaries, many of who dubbed his Alaska purchase “Seward’s Folly.” All Alaskans—and Americans—can be grateful William Seward withstood the criticism and had the wisdom to know how much Alaska could contribute to the rest of the nation. Happy Seward’s Day, Alaska!

It was a great honor this weekend to receive the President’s Legacy and Leadership Award from Healthy Alaska Natives’ Foundation at the Raven’s Ball in Anchorage. Since coming to Congress, I’ve appreciated the opportunity to work with Alaska’s many tribal health advocates on a number of priorities, including a grant program that passed the Senate and was signed into law last year authorizing $300 million for water and wastewater infrastructure needs in small and disadvantaged communities. I also want to congratulate Dr. Thomas Bornstein, Doctor Rita Blumenstein, and Samuel Johns, the foundation’s other honorees, for their inspiring work to improve the health of our communities.

President Trump yesterday signed yet another Congressional Review Act resolution rolling back an Obama-era rule that would have negatively impacted Alaska. In the last weeks of the Obama administration, the Bureau of Land Management issued its “Planning 2.0” rule, which undercut meaningful input from Alaskans, the state, and local communities. The rule also gave outside special interest groups the same influence as Alaskans in the planning process. I want to congratulate Congressman Young and Senator Murkowski on getting this important resolution passed.

Alaska’s world-class Spartans have a new commander. Colonel Paul Larson assumed the leadership of the 4-25 Airborne Infantry Brigade Combat Team in a change of command ceremony with the departure of Colonel Scott Green. I want to extend my thanks to Colonel Green for his years of service, and also to welcome Colonel Larson to Alaska. The 4-25 – America’s only Airborne Brigade in the Arctic and Asia-Pacific – is incredibly important to our nation’s defense, and I’m proud to have worked with a number of advocates, in Alaska and in Washington, fighting to keep the brigade in Alaska.

Senator Lisa Murkowski and I had a BIG group of young Alaskans visit with us on the steps of the Capitol today. The students, here with the Close Up program and 4H, came from Cordova High, Juneau-Douglas High, Ketchikan High, Petersburg High, and West Anchorage High. They had great questions and it was a pleasure to welcome them to Washington.

Many Vietnam veterans didn't receive the welcome home they deserved, even though they had faithfully answered their nation's call. Today we extend our gratitude to veterans of the Vietnam War for their bravery and patriotism. Last weekend, I had the opportunity to mark the occasion with Alaskans at the 6th Annual Alaska Vietnam Veterans Welcome Home Ceremony & Panel Discussion. There were many distinguished veterans in attendance who continue to selflessly support other veterans and service members. Few have dedicated as much time and energy as retired Air Force Colonel and founder of the Alaska Veterans Museum, Suellyn Novak. She was appropriately honored with a beautiful handmade quilt for her unwavering dedication to serving Alaska's veterans. Thank you, Suellyn, for looking after those who have served us so honorably.

We are live celebrating the 150th anniversary of the Alaska Purchase at the National Press Club in Washington, DC with First Lady Donna Walker, Senator Lisa Murkowski, Congressman Don Young, and Alaska Historical Commission Member Jonathan Ross.

We had a wonderful reception tonight commemorating the 150th Anniversary of the Treaty of Cession, which transferred the territory of Alaska from Russia to the United States. It was great to see so many Alaskans together this far from home. I want to thank U.S. Under Secretary of State Thomas Shannon for his insights into the history of the treaty and Secretary of State William H. Seward, and for hosting us at the State Department.

With our thousands of miles of coastline, Alaskans understand better than most the threats of marine debris to our treasured natural areas and iconic wildlife species. I joined a bipartisan group of senators in introducing the Save Our Seas Act which will hold accountable the countries responsible for the majority of the debris in our oceans.
