The bill encourages the Trump administration to forge alliances with these countries and to take a stand against the dangerous levels of debris in our oceans and make sure that they do not reach America’s coastlines. We'll work to educate our Senate colleagues on the crisis, and ensure NOAA has the necessary resources to clean our beaches and protect our coastlines for future generations.

This week, the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee held a hearing on the need to clean up our nation's Cold War legacy sites. Sarah Lukin, of Port Lions, shared the concerns of Alaska Natives who, in some cases, have received contaminated lands from the federal government, and could be held liable for the clean-up. Clean up of these sites is clearly a responsibility of the federal government, and I want to thank Sarah for bringing her expertise and the perspective of Alaskans to the committee.

Congratulations to all of the awardees at the RAM Alaska Rodeo Awards ceremony this weekend in Anchorage. I want to thank Frank Koloski and Stephen Primera for welcoming Julie and me to share in the fun and festivities, and for all you do to support Alaska’s veterans. I also want to encourage Alaskans to make it to the rodeo circuit this summer!

This year, I had the opportunity to select Alaska’s representative to the Cherry Blossom Princess Program. Caitlin Sweeney is an Iñupiat Alaskan originally from Barrow and currently is pursuing a degree in hotel administration from Cornell University. She is a fantastic role model for younger Alaskans, serving on the executive board of the non-profit organization, Cayuga’s Watchers, and volunteering as a tutor for Native American students in the greater Ithaca area. Congratulations, Caitlin!

The U.S. Coast Guard launched its newest cutter this weekend, named for World War II hero Petty Officer Douglas Munro who gave his life while evacuating 500 Marines from Guadalcanal. Munro is the only member of the U.S. Coast Guard ever to receive the Medal of Honor. I had the honor of joining Coast Guard Commandant Admiral Paul Zukunkft at the unveiling of this impressive new vessel in Seattle. The USCG Munro and crew will no doubt carry on the courage and spirit of its namesake. Semper Paratus.

Chinese President Xi Jinping plans to visit the U.S. – and President Trump – later this week. In advance of his visit, Senator Ben Cardin (D-MD) and I, along with a bipartisan group of 24 other senators, sent a letter urging President Trump to call on President Xi to reexamine China’s opposition to the THAAD missile defense system on the Korean Peninsula, which is entirely the result of North Korea’s continue aggressive behavior. We hope President Trump will also discuss with President Xi how China can play a more productive role in achieving the denuclearization of North Korea.

UPDATED TIME: 5:30pm Alaska time Alaskans - this Thursday, I am hosting a Facebook Live event at 5:30pm Alaska time regarding the nomination of Judge Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court. Please share your questions below in the comments section, or post them in the feed during the event, and I will get to as many as I can. Hope you can join me on Thursday!

According to U.S. officials, North Korea last night conducted another missile test, speculated to be a KN-15 medium-range missile using solid-fueled propulsion. I pressed General John Hyten, commander of U.S. Strategic Command, on what the development of solid-fuel propelled rockets means for North Korea’s missile capabilities, and whether we are advancing our own missile defense capabilities quickly enough to stay ahead of this rapidly evolving threat.

The Senate Commerce Committee today voted unanimously to advance the Save Our Seas Act, which will help address the global marine debris crisis impacting America’s coastal ecosystems and communities. Senator Whitehouse (D-RI) and I today discussed the ramifications of garbage being deposited into the oceans, and how the Save Our Seas Act can help form international cooperation toward addressing and mitigating the problem.

Tonight I had the opportunity to recognize a great Alaskan, husband, father, state leader and my good friend: Dan Fauske. Dan passed away this afternoon after decades of service to Alaska – at the North Slope Borough, the Alaska Housing Finance Corporation and the Alaska Gasline Development Corporation. Our prayers and the prayers of so many Alaskans go out to his vivacious and very strong wife Elaine, his children, and his extended family. My family and I, along with so many Alaskans, will miss him greatly.

I will be live discussing the nomination of Judge Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court at 5:30pm Alaska time (9:30 ET). Please write your questions or thoughts in the comments section, and let me know where in Alaska you are from. See you then!

I commend the brave young men and women in the U.S. military for carrying out President Trump’s orders tonight against the regime of Bashar al-Assad in Syria. President Trump stated that Assad had crossed lines by using banned chemical weapons against his own people, and this time, the President of the United States acted. I applaud the President for taking this decisive action, which was focused on degrading Syria’s ability to undertake chemical attacks in the future.   Going forward, we must continue the difficult task of reestablishing U.S. credibility in the region by working closely with our allies to advance our collective security interests, and ensuring that Assad does not commit further chemical attacks against his own people or his neighbors.

The U.S. Army announced today it has formally decided to retain – in its entirety – the 4th Brigade Combat Team (Airborne), 25th Infantry Division at JBER. My team and I have relentlessly advocated for the Army to reverse its planned reduction and keep its only airborne brigade combat team in both the Arctic and Asia-Pacific regions in Alaska. This is an important day for Alaska, and for our national security interests. I want to thank Army leadership, as well as Senator Murkowski, Congressman Young, and the entire Alaska community for helping to show how strategically important this brigade – and all of Alaska’s military – is to the country. Finally, I want to thank the men and women of the 4-25 and their families. You and your families represent America’s finest. Godspeed on your next deployment. Sparta Lives!
Wishing all Alaskans a Happy #NationalBeerDay!
Congratulations to Judge Neil Gorsuch, the newest justice of the Supreme Court. I was proud to cast my vote today to confirm this eminently qualified man to the nation’s highest court.

Thank you to all of the Alaskans who came out for Go Blue Rallies across the state this week, helping raise awareness of Child Abuse Prevention Month. Alaska Children's Trust does incredible work ensuring kids in our communities have safe and nurturing upbringings.

I was honored to be invited to the White House to meet with a number of our courageous military service members who are here for a four-day Wounded Warrior Project "Soldier Ride," cycling through our nation's capital and across the country for a worthy cause. God bless our wounded warriors and their families.

A group of veterans met at Fort Richardson National Cemetery last week to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the United States' entry into First World War. Among the 21 WWI vets who rest at Ft. Rich is Kermit Roosevelt, son of President Teddy Roosevelt, who served honorably in both world wars. At the ceremony, local volunteer bugler Gene Horner played Taps on a WWI-era bugle. Gene has volunteered his bugle services at nearly every memorial service and event in recent memory, making sure that our veterans get the honors they deserve when they are laid to rest. It is important that we never forget the sacrifices made by those who defended our freedom. I commend our Alaska veteran volunteers for always honoring their legacy.
Had a great time meeting with a group of Alaska students from Bethel Regional High School, visiting our nation’s capital with the Close Up Program. Go Warriors!

Alaska was hit hard with news over the holidays that the Obama administration was withdrawing oil and gas leasing opportunities in almost all of the Beaufort and Chukchi Seas. Senator Murkowski and I recently introduced the OPENS Alaska Act, which would repeal those withdrawals, and ensure Alaska receives its fair share of the revenues from offshore development. We know that oil and gas will be developed in the Arctic – whether by our nation or others. It is imperative that this activity occurs with all of the safeguards required by the United States to protect the environment and the people who live in the region.
I hope Alaska’s Jewish community had a wonderful Passover, commemorating the Exodus of the Israelites from Egypt. Chag Sameach!

Today at the United Nations, Russia vetoed a resolution condemning Syria's recent use of sarin gas against its own people, years after the regime supposedly disposed of its chemical weapons. The resolution would have called on the Assad regime to cooperate with an investigation and "provide access for investigators and information such as flight plans." I echo Secretary Tillerson's call on Russia to decide if it thinks covering for the heinous actions of this murderous regime, and standing side-by-side with Iran and North Korea against the rest of the world is really in Russia's longterm interests.

It was an exciting day for the community of Ketchikan with the commissioning of the U.S. Coast Guard Cutter John McCormick. The 154-foot-long, state-of-the-art vessel is the "first of six fast response cutters that will homeport in Alaska." Considering the Coast Guard's vital role in protecting Alaska's marine environment, defending our coastlines, and implementing search-and-rescue, these impressive ships are a wise investment for our state and our nation. Thank you to the crew of the John McCormick, and to all of Alaska's Coasties, for always being ready to answer the call.

Just finished up five days of reserve duty at Camp Lejeune, North Carolina with the Marine Corps Forces Special Operations Command. It's always inspiring to spend time with men and women who live lives of honor, courage and commitment. It's also a reminder, as we move into the Easter weekend, that thousands of members of our military, State Department, and clandestine services are on duty keeping our nation safe. Let's remember them and their families as we celebrate this weekend.

I want to recommend Fox News' recent weeklong series on the opioid crisis. Addressing this issue for Alaskans and those across our country will continue to be one of my highest priorities. We must do more to further our understanding in order to fight this epidemic is ravaging communities across America.

It’s a glorious Easter Sunday in Anchorage. My family and I will be headed to mass soon to celebrate His rising and the washing away of our sins. We’ll say a prayer for all of you, for people of faith who are persecuted around the world, and for our servicemen and women who are keeping us safe. I hope you are enjoying a restful, blessed day with family and friends. Happy Easter Alaska!
Enjoyed some Easter spring skiing this afternoon with my daughter Laurel at Alyeska.
There's no place I'd rather be on Easter Day than with my daughter Laurel, on the slopes at Alyeska. It's a slice of heaven up here -- the most beautiful place in the world.

Great day yesterday on the North Slope with the Alaska Delegation, Lt. Governor Mallott and some of Alaska's business leaders to celebrate the activity happening in Prudhoe, to include the launch of Quintillion's subsea fiber optic cable line and a tour of Hilcorp's Innovation rig.
I'll be hosting a community meet and greet on Friday afternoon in Homer. I hope you can stop by the City of Homer Port and Harbor between 1:30-2:30pm, to say hello.

Surrounded by the Kenai Mountains and the beautiful waters of Kachemak Bay, I talked to Homer residents this afternoon about healthcare, fishing, education, and so many other issues that Alaskans are concerned about. Thanks for having me Homer and for such a nice welcome!

I had a great time visiting with 8th graders at Romig Middle School. It was perfect timing as they were preparing for a "Mock Congress" debate. I am always humbled when visiting Alaska's young leaders - they asked smart, tough questions, ranging from Russian long-range bombers, to the President's budget, to funding for Essential Air Service. I am sure their debates rival anything we see in the Senate! A special thanks to teacher Amber Sherwood and Principal Sven Gustafson for the invitation and warm welcome - two of Alaska's incredible educators. Thank you for all you do.

Alaskan WWII and Korean War veterans returned home today from a trip to Washington, DC. Ron Travis and the Honor Flight program volunteers who make this happen are truly amazing. Our veterans are a national treasure and it is heartwarming to see the Alaskan community come together to honor them in this way. It is important that we thank our veterans every chance we get for their service and sacrifice. Welcome home!

Thank you so much to Principal Catherine Neumayr and all of the fantastic 3rd - 12th grade students at Holy Rosary Academy for inviting me to visit. My first question was from a bright little girl who asked me if I know what BSEE is. I replied, "Yes!" It's a really important agency for Alaska - and she shared that her dad works there. I loved ending our visit (complete with more insightful questions about immigration, the Marines, and Syria) by joining the students in singing the National Anthem and the Alaska Flag Song. And to top it all off, they shared some very delicious cake. What a great day.

I have much respect for former U.S. Surgeon General Vivek Murthy’s Turn the Tide campaign to combat the opioid epidemic that is destroying some communities across the country. I am particularly grateful for his willingness to come to Alaska to participate in our Wellness Summit last summer. I hope that the new surgeon general puts the same emphasis and passion into fighting this deadly crisis affecting so many across our state and our country.

The world yesterday marked Yom HaShoah, Holocaust Remembrance Day, and the White House has proclaimed this week the Days of Remembrance for Victims of the Holocaust –calling to mind one of the most horrific periods in human history. In Israel, the entire nation paused – “pedestrians stood in place, buses stopped on busy streets and cars pulled over on major highways” – as haunting sirens rang out, a solemn reminder of the 6 million Jewish lives tragically lost in the Holocaust. We must remain vigilant in the face of hatred that seeks to undermine the dignity and value of any human being, and ensure that such atrocities are never again allowed to take place.

I want to congratulate members of our Alaska National Guard Rescue Squadrons and the Rescue Coordination Center for winning the 2016 Jolly Green Association Rescue Mission of the Year. According to the Air Force, the multi-day rescue mission conducted on Harding Icefield last year saved two lives and was “the most outstanding USAF Personnel Recovery mission of 2016.” Congrats to all involved for the well-deserved recognition!

I want to thank Anchorage Police Chief Chris Tolley for his nearly two years serving as chief and more than two decades with the department. Captain Justin Doll, who will be assuming the role of chief, is a fellow Marine who I have had the honor of serving with. I am confident he will bring the same high standards and determination to leading Anchorage’s brave law enforcement officers who dedicate their lives to keeping our community safe.
My thoughts following a meeting at the White House with the entire U.S. Senate regarding the continuing threat posed by North Korea to our Asia-Pacific allies and our homeland.

Congressman Young, Senator Murkowski and I welcomed a big group of Alaskan students to D.C. this week. They hailed from Colony High in Palmer, Redington High in Wasilla, Wrangell High, South High in Anchorage, and Voznesenka School on the Kenai Peninsula. Glad to get the chance to take their questions and hear what their plans are for the future!

In case you missed it, I joined Morning Joe on MSNBC today to discuss yesterday’s meeting with all U.S. Senators at the White House regarding the North Korean threat. On matters as grave and important as this, America’s foreign policy is most effective when the executive branch and the Congress – Democrats and Republicans alike – are on the same page and working together.

One of the drivers of the opioid epidemic is the wide availability of unused and unneeded prescription drugs. Most abused prescription drugs come from family and friends. Tomorrow, National Prescription Drug Take Back Day, from 10:00am to 2:00pm, you will have an opportunity to safely dispose of medications you no longer need. Together let’s make sure that they don’t fall into the wrong hands. If you are not near a take-back site, you can find tips on how to safely dispose of unused drugs yourself at: https://sen.gov/RW02

Last December, Alaskans were outraged when President Obama unilaterally placed nearly the entire Arctic Ocean off-limits to energy development. Today, President Trump undertook the first steps to right this wrong for Alaskans and for our country. Production is increasing in Alaska, and there are new oil finds throughout the state. Alaska is on the brink of leading our country into a new energy renaissance. With a White House working with Congress—and acting as a partner with Alaska—responsible production of our energy resources will strengthen our national security, provide good jobs for thousands of Alaskans, and help grow the economies of our state and our country.

Alaska vets – I’m sorry to inform you of a potential phone  scam that has recently surfaced. The VA brought to my attention an imposter phone line for the Veterans Choice Program using a similar number that veterans may inadvertently call. The real VCP line is 1.866.606.8198, while the scam line is a 1-800 number with the same digits. The fake phone line offers a rebate in exchange for your credit card number. Please be careful when dialing, and if you have any questions, feel free to reach out to my office at 907.271.5915.

I spoke yesterday on the Senate floor to recognize Madison Englund, of Fairbanks, and Jennifer Troutman, of Anchorage, two exceptional athletes who are our Alaskans of the Week. Madison and Jennifer each brought home medals from the 2017 Special Olympics World Winter Games in Austria. Congratulations Madison and Jennifer!

Next month, I’ll be participating in the Alaska Healthy Futures’ 100 Miles in May Challenge – and I hope you’ll join me! Alaska Healthy Futures’ goal is to “empower Alaska’s youth to build the habit of daily physical activity.” All you have to do is log 100 miles of physical activity over the course of the month. Learn more about the challenge, and how you can convert a variety of activities into mileage at:

I recently welcomed a friend and key Alaskan advocate to Washington – Kara Nelson, director of Juneau’s Haven House who was part of the group of women who inspired last year’s Alaska Wellness Summit. FBI Director Jim Comey presented Kara with the Community Leadership Award, given to a select group of Americans each year in recognition of their work to combat crime, drugs and violence. Kara is a truly great Alaskan who has put so much passion and drive behind turning the tide on the opioid epidemic, serving as a support and a resource for those currently and formerly incarcerated, and helping so many Alaskans in recovery. I can’t think of anyone more deserving of this recognition.
Just heard news that Southeast was awoken to a series of strong morning earthquakes. Glad to see initial reports show no significant damage, injuries, or tsunami warnings. Stay safe!

I had the honor of speaking recently at the American Bar Association in support of Legal Services Corporation and the important work Alaska Legal Services Corporation does in our state to provide pro bono legal services, including for victims of domestic violence and sexual assault. I am now working with my colleague Senator Heitkamp, and a number of cosponsors in the Senate and the House, to bring that work to the national level with the POWER Act. I envision an army of pro-bono lawyers across the country working to help end the cycle of abuse.

Welcome to Alaska, sailors of the USS Hopper. The dedicated men and women of the United States Navy are always ready to defend our nation by sea. The world-class combined arms training opportunities that Alaska has to offer are a key factor in their superior readiness. I commend the Navy and those serving on the USS Hopper for their commitment to ensuring the safest training and least impact, while maximizing the benefits to the preparedness of our nation’s defense. Thank you all for your service to our nation!

My lab Maddie may be a little jealous. Today I got to meet “Rumor,” the five-year-old German Shepherd who took home Best in Show at the 2017 Westminster Dog Show. Rumor was at the Capitol today with a number of other dogs for National Purebred Dog Day.

My focus on America’s stagnant economic growth does not change just because we have a new administration. Just as I criticized the Obama administration for never hitting 3% growth in a single year, I think the Trump administration should be held to the same standard. These first quarter numbers are discouraging, and reinforce for me the urgency of reigniting the American economy. Achieving historic averages of 3-4% GDP growth would do wonders for individual Americans looking for work, and for their families. I think the new administration’s focus on regulatory reform, increasing energy production, and boosting job creation is the right approach.

DC is rocked every year when a parade of vets on bikes come to town for Rolling Thunder—but this week it’s STROLLING Thunder. Young families are here from all 50 states to advocate for what babies and toddlers need in their early years of development. I welcomed the Harvey family from Eagle River. Their two girls were inquisitive and full of energy – strong advocates for Alaska.
Senator Murkowski and I had a blast today meeting with students from Unalaska!

Twenty-nine teachers from all across Alaska were honored this week as BP’s 2017 Teachers of Excellence. Heather Roach, a chemistry teacher at East Anchorage High School, has served as an educator for 22 years and received the Teacher of the Year Award. Ms. Roach started Alaska’s first robotics club which sent teams to the first-ever National Robotics Challenge. Congratulations, Ms. Roach and to the other distinguished educators, and thank you for the passion and hard work you devote to seeing our young people succeed.

The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals covers a population 85% bigger than the next largest circuit. Alaskans and those living under the Ninth Circuit’s jurisdiction wait 40% longer to access justice. The Ninth Circuit, weighted down by three times the pending appeals of the next largest circuit, employs procedural shortcuts – “fast food justice” as I call it – not used by other circuits. This morning, I shared with Fox & Friends the strong case to be made for dividing this overburdened circuit, as has been done numerous times throughout history, to preserve equal access to justice for the 1-in-5 Americans living under the Ninth Circuit.

The Senate today took an important vote on funding the government through September 30. While I continue to believe that the process by which we fund the government is fundamentally flawed, the bill we passed will provide the necessary funding to keep the government open for the remainder of the fiscal year – which gives agencies greater fiscal certainty. After years of cuts to our military – which I have repeatedly fought against – we voted to significantly increase spending on our men and women in the U.S. military to address the growing national security threats throughout the world, while not having to simultaneously increase funding for domestic agencies like the EPA or the IRS.   The bill also funds many agencies and programs vital to our state, including NOAA, the Coast Guard’s Arctic priorities, the Essential Air Service program, infrastructure investments across the state, and community health centers – all of which I’ve been pressing for during my tenure in the U.S. Senate. I’m also pleased that the bill provides more than a billion dollars to address the opioid and heroin epidemic facing our nation – which is an issue I have been very focused on. This is a good start, but we need to do much more to turn the tide.

The airmen of the U.S. Air Force’s 3rd Wing and the Alaska National Guard continue to demonstrate their professionalism in response to the most recent Russian incursion into the U.S. Air Defense Zone near Chariot, Alaska. As Russia continues to fly bombers – and for the first time, Su-35 fighter aircraft – off the coast of Alaska, I am proud to know that U.S. Air Force F-22s, AWACS, KC-135 tankers, and many Alaska Guardsmen stand ready to immediately defend the great State of Alaska and America's sovereignty.

Congratulations to the young men and women of the West Anchorage Air Force JROTC for their outstanding performance today in the 2017 National High School Drill Team Championships. You are representing Alaska and the JROTC programs well. Keep up the good work!

Today we honor the sacrifices made by the law enforcement heroes of the Last Frontier, both past and present. Alaskans rely on their bravery and professionalism in moments of crisis. We owe a profound debt of gratitude to the courageous men and women who stand on the front lines to keep our communities safe.

Got home last night and was delighted to meet students from Teeland Middle School and their parents and teachers who were on the same flight. They had just spent the past week on the East Coast studying and experiencing U.S. history first hand - Gettysburg, Mount Vernon, Philadelphia, the monuments of Washington, D.C. Great job to our smart students and their outstanding teachers and dedicated parents. A special shout out to Mr. Childs, teaching 8th grade U.S. History with obvious passion.   If you are a teacher or parent leading a similar trip, please reach out to me and my office. We'd love to see you and help you with any tours in D.C!
Speaking live on the Senate floor about how the United States should approach its relationship with China – an important global power.

Alaskans – this Friday at 5:30pm, I will be holding a constituent town hall in North Pole. I look forward to this opportunity to engage on the issues important to Alaska and our country, and to hear directly from you. I hope to see you there!

Many small Alaskan communities, particularly in the Chugach and Tongass National Forests, rely on the Secure Rural Schools Program to fund a variety of services, including infrastructure, education and public safety. SRS was established to support communities that have suffered in recent years from decreased timber production on federal lands. Senator Murkowski and I have been working to get this program renewed since its expiration at the end of Fiscal Year 2015. I appreciate Majority Leader McConnell coming to the Senate floor to recognize the importance of SRS, and for his commitment to help see this program reauthorized.

I joined U.S. Chief of Naval Operations Admiral Richardson today at the Tingey House, on the grounds of the oldest shore establishment of the U.S. Navy, and one of the few buildings to survive the burning of Washington by the British during the War of 1812. We discussed a range important matters including the need for icebreakers and increased naval operations in the Arctic. We also discussed the importance of routine and regular freedom of navigation operations across the globe, including in places like the South China Sea. Lastly, I mentioned to the Admiral the great reception the people of Homer gave the brave men and women on the USS Hopper - a U.S. Navy destroyer - during her recent port visit in Alaska. Great job, Homer!

President Trump has the authority to choose the director of the FBI whom he believes will best lead the agency. The timing of the president’s firing of Director James Comey raises questions that will need to be answered by the administration. I am hopeful that the administration will put forward an independent and strong leader of the FBI. Once the Senate receives the nomination, I look forward to a rigorous, fair and timely confirmation process.   During this transition phase, we need to continue the comprehensive investigations being conducted by both the FBI and the Senate Intelligence Committee into Russia’s involvement in the 2016 election, and the possible illegal unmasking of private citizens by federal officials. These investigations need to be free of political interference.  The rule of law is the foundation of our Democracy. It should apply equally to all, including the White House, the FBI, the IRS and the Justice Department. Unfortunately, it has been eroded over the past several years. We, both Democrats and Republicans, need to work on reestablishing and safeguarding this critically important American ideal.

Senator Murkowski and I had a great time meeting with students from Girdwood Middle School who are visiting Washington this week. The students also had the opportunity to hear from a third Alaskan working in the U.S. Senate – fellow Girdwoodian, Wade Quigley, who is doing a fantastic job serving as a Senate page.

The eyes of the world are on Fairbanks this week as dignitaries and leaders gather for the 10th Arctic Council Ministerial. I want to thank Secretary Tillerson for traveling to Alaska and for making it clear that the Arctic is a priority for the new administration. Before departing for Fairbanks, I spoke on the Senate floor on the importance of this occasion, and the enormous opportunities we have in the Arctic.
Fairbanks has done a fantastic job hosting the 10th Ministerial of the Arctic Council, marking the conclusion of the United States' chairmanship which now passes to Finland.

I had a whirlwind couple of days visiting with a number of Alaskans last weekend. We kicked it off with the Amblin’ for Alzheimer’s Walk, helping to raise awareness and funds to combat a disease that affects so many families, including my own. After cheering Laurel on at her track meet at Dimond, I stopped by the Alaska Gun Collectors Association Show, the oldest and largest in Alaska, showing off incredible collections and historical items. Then I spoke with pilots and others at the 20th Annual Great Alaska Aviation Gathering, the premier venue for aviation enthusiasts in Alaska, the “flying-est” state in the Union. Lastly, I was honored to help present 2017 Missile Defender and Base Defender of the Year Awards to a number of hard-working and well-deserving Alaska Guardsmen who keep the homeland safe. Altogether, a great weekend.
Grateful to have an Interior Secretary intent on filling the Trans Alaska Pipeline. God bless you Ryan Zinke!

Mothers all across our great state and country teach us about love and courage. Every day, they inspire us to be better people, to work harder and to give more of ourselves. Happy Mother’s Day to all of the mothers in Alaska and thank you for all you do to shape the character of our state. And Happy Mother’s Day to my wife Julie, my mom Sandy and my mother-in-law Mary Jane Fate. Meghan, Isabella, Laurel and I love and honor you all very, very much. https://sen.gov/9ZV6

The community of Homer knows Sherry Bess for her nearly three decades caring for abused and abandoned animals – roughly 1,200 per year with the help of a dedicated group of Alaskans. I spoke on the Senate floor to recognize Sherry’s efforts to take care of and find homes for animals who, in her words, were “unwanted and sad and depressed.” Thank you, Sherry, for your heart for service, for the happiness you’ve brought to so many Alaskan families and for being our Alaskan of the Week.

One of the best parts of my job is getting to nominate young men and women to America’s service academies. Recently, I ran into one of these young leaders, Andrew Hampton, who I had the pleasure of nominating to West Point. Congratulations, Andrew, and to all of the exceptional young Alaskans who will be attending one of these prestigious institutions.

I had a great visit to Galena on a beautiful spring day with ice flowing down the mighty Yukon River. Special thanks to Mayor Jon Korta, Louden Tribal Council Chief Jenny Pelkola and Galena City School District Superintendent Chris Reitan for hosting me. I met with community members at the annual spring outdoor flea market before touring the new biomass heating project for the Galena Interior Learning Academy. Then I had a delicious lunch of moose soup and baked salmon while meeting with local leaders to hear their priorities before heading to the elder facility to watch GILA boarding students perform Native song & dance and answer questions from community members. Thank you, Galena, for the warm welcome and hospitality!

During Police Week, we remember the sacrifices made by our many brave law enforcement officers in Alaska and across the country who risk their lives to keep our communities safe. Today I visited the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial where the name of fallen Fairbanks Police Sergeant Allen Brandt was recently added in honor of his heroism and selflessness.

I want to thank the people of the Interior and Galena for joining me last week for engaging and productive discussions about their concerns and priorities. This Saturday, I’ll be hosting another town hall, this time in Anchorage. It is an honor to serve you, and I hope you are able to join.

With front-page news today of a massive spike in heroin overdoses in the Anchorage area, Alaskans are rightly concerned about the progress being made against the persistent opioid epidemic affecting so many. Today, the Senate Commerce Committee held a hearing on the health and safety of athletes, including issues of opioid abuse by athletes of all ages and levels. Among the witnesses was Dr. Jay Butler, Alaska’s chief medical officer, who provided great insight into the work being done in Alaska to better respond to overdoses and prevent individuals from falling into the trap of addiction.

While I continue to have confidence in the Senate Intelligence Committee's thorough and bipartisan investigation, I also respect the Department of Justice's independent decision to appoint a special counsel. Former FBI Director and Marine, Robert Mueller, has a well-earned reputation as a man of character and integrity and will give this matter the seriousness it deserves.

I had good visit with a group of Fairbanks police officers and their families, in Washington for National Police Week and to honor a fallen colleague, Sergeant Allen Brandt, one of the 143 officers killed in the line of duty last year. I discussed with them the challenges departments face in recruiting new officers during a time when those who keep us safe are often under-appreciated, sometimes maligned and even targeted. They put their lives on the line for us every day. We need to show our brave men and women in blue that we have their back and that we appreciate all they do for our communities. Thank you Chief Jewkes and all of Alaska’s law enforcement officers for keeping Alaskans safe.

I spoke on the Senate floor yesterday in recognition of a great Alaskan - Michael Carson, of Palmer, an avid community volunteer and the co-founder of MYHouse resource center for homeless youth. Michael, thank you for all you do to help our young people and those struggling with addiction, and congratulations on being our Alaskan of the week.

Today, Armed Forces Day, we salute the brave men and women who serve in the Air Force, Army, Coast Guard, Marine Corps, and Navy. We are proud of all of the sacrifices you make, defending the homeland and maintaining peace throughout the world. God bless each you and your families.

Over the last several years, we have witnessed an uptick in attacks on our first responders both in Alaska and across the country. During Police Week, I reintroduced the “Protect Our Heroes” Act, which would make the assault or killing of a public safety officer a federal crime. It also includes an additional penalty for luring an officer to a location for an ambush attack. We must do everything we can to promote a system of law and order which enables police officers, first responders and public safety officials to properly do their jobs with as little risk as possible to their safety and well-being.

This weekend, Julie and I stopped by the Anchorage Barefoot Mile, which raises awareness about the scourge of human trafficking. Thank you to Davis Constructors for helping to organize the event, along with Joy International, Covenant House, MYHouse, and Priceless. And a big thank you to Dr. Jeff Brodsky, a tireless advocate for victims of trafficking, who has spent nearly seven years barefoot to bring greater attention to the cause.
I want to wish my friend and colleague Lisa Murkowski a very happy birthday! It is an honor getting to serve Alaskans alongside you.

Top military leaders have been sounding the alarm, saying it is only a matter of "when, not if," Kim Jong-un will get the capability to range cities in the United States with a nuclear inter-continental ballistic missile. Today I introduced the Advancing America’s Missile Defense Act, which heeds that warning and seeks to advance our nation’s ability to outpace the current threats. I thank my colleagues on both sides of aisle - Senators Schatz (D-HI), Cruz (R-TX), Peters (D-MI), Cotton (R-AR), Manchin (D-WV), Rubio (R-FL) and Capito (R-WV) - for coming together to address this critical national security issue.

I was so pleased to be able to stand alongside Alaska's law enforcement community on Saturday morning at the Law Enforcement Torch Run in support of our amazing Special Olympians. I got to cheer on many friends, like Jan Pendleton and Joe Pichler, and catch up with the incoming APD Chief, Captain Justin Doll, whom I had the honor of serving with in the Marines. Can't think of a better way to start the day than cheering on so many inspiring Alaskans for a great cause.

The White House today released its proposed fiscal year 2018 budget request. As I have said before, it’s important to remember that Congress holds the power of the purse, and will ultimately fund the federal government.  From my initial review, I see some positive elements in the budget request, such as opening the non-wilderness 1002 area for responsible resource development, and a continued increase in funding for combatting our nation’s opioid and heroin epidemic – something that I’ve strongly advocated for.  With regard to defense spending, while the President’s budget proposal is an improvement and an increase over the severely-depressed Obama-era defense budgets, and includes $170 million of military construction for Alaska, I remain concerned that – in an increasingly dangerous world – this budget proposal does not provide enough resources to really begin rebuilding our military.   I am strongly opposed to specific reductions in this budget that disproportionately target rural economies across our country, including in Alaska – cutting funds for Essential Air Service, water and wastewater infrastructure, low-income heating assistance, and critical education programs.  In the months ahead, I’ll be working with the other members of the Alaska Delegation to fight for programs and funding that are vital for Alaska and will help grow our economy.

Today I helped pass a major VA accountability bill, which I cosponsored, out of the Veterans’ Affairs Committee. The legislation sets a more reasonable bar for the dismissal or demotion of VA employees that are failing our veterans, and gives the VA Secretary the tools and flexibility he needs to transform the culture at the VA. We can’t restore veterans’ trust in the VA overnight, but this bill is a big step in the right direction.

America's missile defense is a critical insurance policy that protects our citizens and our allies from a nuclear catastrophe. I spoke on the Senate floor today about the Advancing America's Missile Defense Act, legislation I introduced Monday that would bolster this vital system, increase testing, and accelerate the development of new technologies needed to keep our capability ahead of the North Korean threat.

I had a great time last weekend at a state regional high school track meet at Dimond, cheering on our young athletes who have worked hard all year. These young women had just completed the 100 meter hurdles (including my youngest daughter, Laurel). Many will be competing today and tomorrow at the state track and field championships in Palmer. Good luck to all of our high school athletes!

This week on the Senate floor, I recognized the recipients of the 2017 Missile & Base Defenders of the Year Awards as our Alaskans of the week: SSgt. Jonathan Rivera-Calderon, SSgt. Stanislav Barilov, Capt. Erik Haugen, TSgt. Mark Lockwood, Sgt. Nathan Williams, Sgt. Travis Hall, Maj. Michael Long, Capt. Anthony Montoya, 1st Lt. Rachel Simmons, SSgt. Caroline Domenech, and Sgt. Jose Aponte. These brave, hard-working Alaska Guardsmen stand watch every day of the year – including this Memorial Day weekend – ready to defend our homeland, and they deserve our gratitude and thanks.
The Washington Post's Josh Rogin penned a great piece on the accelerating North Korean missile threat, and the Advancing America’s Missile Defense Act, which I introduced this week. Take a read:

This week, I welcomed nine Alaskan students from all corners of Alaska – Togiak, Shishmaref, Nikiski, St. Mary’s, Akiachak, Seward and Bethel. They are in Washington with the Upward Bound Program, which prepares students for success in their postsecondary education. Great to meet each of these motivated young women!

NORAD, the North American Aerospace Defense Command, is a bi-national organization that exemplifies the close relationship between the U.S. and Canada. The Deputy Commander for the Alaska NORAD region – based at JBER – is actually a Canadian, Brigadier-General Laroche. Earlier this week, I once again had the pleasure of meeting with General Laroche’s boss, Canada’s Minister of National Defense Harjit Sajjan – the equivalent of our nation’s Secretary of Defense. We discussed the importance of Arctic cooperation, the need for NORAD modernization, and our close energy and trade relationships. I appreciated the great conversation and look forward to working with Minister Sajjan in the future.

It has been a tragic few days with two plane crashes, one taking the lives of Buzz Otis and Sam Brice - anchors of the Interior community - and the other taking the lives of two near Haines. Julie and I are praying for Buzz and Sam’s family and friends, and those of the victims in Southeast, mourning their loved ones this Memorial Day weekend.

I had the honor of giving the Memorial Day address at the Alaska Veterans Memorial in Anchorage today where hundreds of patriotic Alaskans showed up to remember those who have sacrificed their lives for us. I was also able to attend the very moving ceremony at Fort Richardson National Cemetery. Wishing all Alaskans a peaceful Memorial Day and let's all remember to say a prayer for the families of our fallen. Never forget.

The successful intercept test today of an ICBM-like target sends a clear message to the unstable dictator in North Korea that the U.S. Ballistic Missile Defense System can and will shoot down any ballistic missile threat that endangers the American people. Today is an important day for our nation’s missile defenders, our scientists and engineers, and the American people. While I am thankful this test was a success, we need to do more to ensure that our missile defense system continues to advance ahead of the rapidly increasing North Korean threat. The strong, bipartisan Advancing America's Missile Defense Act, which I introduced last week, will do just that.

It was an honor to be able to convene a historic meeting between Secretary Zinke and Alaska Native veterans from across the state to hear their concerns, particularly the need to address the allotment some of them missed due to prior military service. Secretary Zinke, a decorated Navy SEAL, got to witness the special patriotism exhibited by Alaska Natives who, generation after generation, have served our country in the military at a higher rate than any other ethnic group. The stories Secretary Zinke heard today were ones I know he will carry with him as he looks to create more opportunity for Alaska Natives and others across the state. I thank Secretary Zinke for coming to our great state and meeting with these great Alaskans.

Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke today issued an order rolling back the Obama administration’s lock-up of resource development in the National Petroleum Reserve-Alaska. Also today, Secretary Zinke announced that Interior will update its geological assessment of ANWR, last completed in the 1980s. During his visit, Zinke has declared an end to the war on North American energy and said, “There is no path to energy dominance that doesn’t go through Alaska.” What a difference six months makes!

I had a great day in the Mighty Mat-Su, meeting with local leaders at the Greater Wasilla Chamber of Commerce where I talked about what we're doing in DC to help lift the burdens on small businesses and to get our economy growing again – and how this new Administration is working with our state as a partner, not an adversary. Then I had a very productive meeting with members of the Mat-Su Opioid Task Force who shared with me their priorities in continuing the fight against this epidemic. I was able to share some good news – the 21st Century Cures Act, which we worked to pass in late 2016, is bringing millions of dollars in new resources to Alaska this year. I am so grateful that this strong group of Alaskans are giving their time and energy to help those suffering from addiction.

I joined Fox & Friends this morning to discuss North Korea’s continued advancement of its ballistic missile and nuclear programs, and bipartisan legislation I introduced last week, the Advancing America’s Missile Defense Act, which would help keep America’s capabilities ahead of the North Korean threat.

Fourteen of my Senate colleagues – Democrats and Republicans alike – have now cosponsored the Advancing America’s Missile Defense Act, which I introduced last week. I joined Paul Gigot on the Journal Editorial Report this weekend to continue to make the case for bolstering America’s missile defense capability now so that we can stay ahead of the rapidly progressing North Korean missile and nuclear threats.

On the evening that U.S. and Allied forces stormed the beaches of Normandy, President Roosevelt called the entire nation to prayer, saying of our troops: “They fight not for the lust of conquest. They fight to end conquest. They fight to let justice arise, and tolerance and goodwill among Thy people.” Today we remember the thousands lost on D-Day, bravely fighting to end the reign of tyranny in a place half way around the world, helping to preserve the hope of freedom for generations to come.

Aleut elders and World War II veterans gathered over the weekend on the 75th Anniversary of the Bombing of Dutch Harbor, sharing personal accounts and stories of the hardships they all experienced. Most Americans are probably unaware that U.S. service members lost their lives defending U.S. territory in the Aleutians against Imperial Japan, and that many Aleuts were interned and faced harsh conditions during the evacuations. I want to thank the City of Dutch Harbor, the Qawalangin Tribe of Unalaska, the Ounalashka Corporation, the crew of U.S. Coast Guard Cutter Midgett, Matson Logistics, the U.S. Park Service and all the volunteers who made this impactful event possible for the surviving veterans and Aleut evacuees.

Today the Senate unanimously passed the VA Accountability and Whistleblower Protection Act, legislation I cosponsored that will finally give VA officials the authority they need to fire bad actors. The vast majority of VA workers do a great job for our veterans. But too many vets have lost confidence in the VA. This legislation is an important step toward restoring that trust.

Check out these spectacular shots from space of a recent eruption of Bogoslof volcano in the Aleutian Chain. The Alaska Volcano Observatory does a great job keeping Alaskans apprised of the rumblings and hazards from the many volcanos in our state.

Earlier today, NASA announced its 2017 Astronaut Candidate Class, and among the twelve selected was an Alaskan. Out of 18,300 applicants, Robb Kulin, of Anchorage, was chosen to be part of this small and incredibly qualified group of individuals that will report to Johnson Space Center for two years of training. According to NASA, the candidates could be assigned to missions on the International Space Station, commercial spacecraft, or the new Orion spacecraft. Best wishes to Robb and the other astronauts as they prepare to explore the final frontier.
I want to wish Vice President Mike Pence a happy birthday. He is a man of character and humility (with a young son in the Marines!), working hard to strengthen our economy and the U.S. military.

I had the opportunity today to question VA Secretary Shulkin about the Choice Program and the future of veteran community care. As we consider a path forward, we cannot – and more importantly, veterans cannot – have a repeat of what happened in Alaska when Choice was initially implemented in 2014. I also thanked the Secretary for announcing a long-recommended, commonsense change – integrating the VA medical records system with that of the Department of Defense to better serve military service members from active duty into veteran life.

Tomorrow, Bear Tooth is hosting another free screening of Chasing the Dragon, an eye-opening documentary produced by the FBI and DEA detailing the harsh experiences of Americans struggling with opioid addiction, as well as the impacts on their families. I was able to attend a screening last year. Events and panel discussions like this are critical to raising awareness, enhancing prevention, and reducing the stigma associated with this devastating epidemic.

This Saturday evening, I’ll be in Kodiak for another community town hall. These events have been great opportunities to hear directly what’s on the minds of Alaskans, including those outside of the Railbelt. I hope to see you there.

Astronaut Candidate Robb Kulin isn’t the only Alaskan making waves at NASA’s Johnson Space Center. This week, students from UAA are participating in the Micro-g Neutral Buoyancy Experiment Design (Micro-g NExT) Program. University teams each designed a tool or device that “addresses an authentic, current space exploration challenge.” While at the Johnson Space Center, UAA students will put their designs to the test at NASA’s Neutral Buoyancy Laboratory, “a 6.2-million-gallon indoor pool used to train NASA astronauts for spacewalks.” Good luck, UAA! Happy Birthday to my friend and colleague Congressman Don Young, a man with a great sense of humor, a deep love for Alaska, and a strong grip. And Happy Anniversary to the Congressman and Anne!

Fishing employs more in Alaska than any other industry, but a number of barriers prevent newer generations from filling the ranks of this vital sector of our economy. Yesterday, Senator Markey (D-MA), Senator Murkowski, Senator Cantwell (D-WA) and I introduced the Young Fishermen’s Development Act, legislation to mitigate some of these challenges and bolster recruiting. Replenishing the stocks of qualified fisheries stewards will help ensure Alaska remains the superpower of seafood.

Yesterday I spoke on the Senate floor in honor of Marty Shroyer, of Kotzebue, our Alaskan of the Week. Marty began making sandwiches over his lunch hour a few days a week for Alaskans he saw in need and has since grown the effort into a community-wide initiative to feed the hungry. Thank you, Marty, for your simple acts of compassion that have inspired so many.
Just a reminder for Alaskans in Kodiak - I'll be hosting a town hall this evening. Hope you can join me.

Best of luck to all of the amazing athletes and unified partners from across Alaska who are in Anchorage this weekend for the 2017 Special Olympics Alaska Summer Games. Thank you to the more than 300 volunteers and 48 coaches who help make these games possible - and of course to the athletes who inspire all of us. Have a wonderful games!

One of Alaska's star athletes Allie Ostrander took home the NCAA Division I 3,000-meter steeplechase title this weekend, "...only the third Alaskan to win a Division I individual track and field national title." Congratulations, Allie, on your impressive achievement!
Grace Schaible, the first woman to serve as Alaska's attorney general, was an inspiration to all of us. Our thoughts and prayers go out to her family and loved ones.

I had a fantastic weekend in Kodiak, and I want to thank the more than 150 Alaskans who joined me for a town hall discussion. Earlier in the day, I met with Marines helping to construct an important runway expansion in Old Harbor, off of Kodiak Island. The Marine Corps Innovative Readiness Training (IRT) program has been a valuable asset in helping rural communities build infrastructure projects. Afterward, I stopped by the community for a meet and greet with a wonderful performance by the Nuniaq Alutiiq Dancers. Thank you for the warm welcome!

The well-being of our seas and coastal ecosystems is a main focus here in Washington during Oceans Week. With more coastline than the Lower 48 states combined, Alaska is at the forefront of these discussions. Stay tuned for updates throughout the week, including the latest on my Save Our Seas Act, legislation to address the global marine debris crisis.

We have several fantastic interns helping out in my Washington, DC office this summer from all across Alaska. If you are a recent high school or college graduate looking to gain some professional experience in our nation’s capital, this could be the opportunity for you!
