I had a great meeting today with Alaskans visiting all the way from the North Slope Borough, America’s Arctic. They generously let me try on a beautiful handcrafted seal-skin tie—something that you won’t see often, if ever, in these parts. These meetings with Alaskans are definitely the best part of my job.

Law enforcement officers across the country, including Capitol police, stand on duty 24/7 ready to sacrifice for others, as we saw today. We are all grateful for their courage. Praying for a speedy recovery for Congressman Scalise and the other victims.

I’d like to wish a happy 242nd birthday to the United States Army! Our Arctic Warriors are some of the most lethal and effective Army forces out there, training in the harshest conditions so that they are ready to get the job done when their nation calls upon them. Hats off to the brave men and women of the U.S. Army. Keep up the great work.

The Senate this week is working on important legislation that would impose new sanctions on Iran in light of the regime’s continued efforts to undermine peace, American interests, and the international order since the signing of President Obama’s Iran nuclear deal. This bipartisan bill is strong, but in my opinion, could be stronger – particularly by preventing Iran from accessing the powerful U.S. financial system as long as the regime is a state sponsor of terrorism.

I want to congratulate the young Alaskans participating in the 2017 National History Day competition this week in DC. Congressman Young, Senator Murkowski and I got to hear about some of their creative research projects exploring different topics and individuals in history. I also want to thank the teachers and parents who have encouraged and supported the students along the way.

Alaska’s Congressman Don Young today introduced House companion legislation to the Advancing America’s Missile Defense (AAMD) Act, which I introduced recently. Also this week, Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis signaled his support for the continued improvement of the U.S. missile defense system, and the need to expand its capabilities as a result of anticipated future threats to the American homeland. I’m glad to see this important legislation continuing to gain traction in light of the evolving threat from North Korea.

My friend Tully and his dad, from Craig, Alaska, stopped by my office this week. Tully aspires to be a Marine when he grows up, and he and his brother check in regularly to give me an update on their studies and life in Craig. We’re all very proud of Tully, a stellar student with a bright future ahead.

For years, Alaskans living in coastal communities have witnessed the threat posed by marine debris, often coming from half a world away. The Save Our Seas Act, which I introduced this spring, is a bipartisan effort clean up our seas and prevent more trash from being dumped into our oceans.

My life has been so blessed by the examples set by my father Tom Sullivan and my father-in-law Bud Fate. Throughout their lives, Bud and Tom have demonstrated the qualities that have made American fathers revered on this day: both served their country in the U.S. military; both worked extremely hard to build successful careers; both gave back to their communities in both big and small ways; and most importantly, both married incredible women and life partners who they have loved, respected, and have been dedicated to for decades. Happy Father’s Day to them and to all of Alaska’s and America’s fathers!

Today I spoke on the Senate floor in recognition of Lee Jordan, of Eagle River, our Alaskan of the Week. Lee has been an instrumental supporter of the Alaska Baseball League and one of two major advocates – along with former state Senator Bill Stoltze – for bringing a team to Eagle River-Chugiak. Lee Jordan thinks the ballpark there is the most beautiful ballpark anywhere, and I can’t disagree. Thank you, Lee, for your strong support of your community and support for this great American pastime.

Chris Oliver is an exceptional choice to lead the National Marine Fisheries Service, the first Alaskan ever to permanently hold this important role. For so many Alaskans and their families, fishing is a way of life. They can rest assured that Alaska’s interests will be well-represented and the concerns and perspectives of commercial, charter, and recreational fishermen alike will be valued at the National Marine Fisheries Service as we work to protect Alaska’s marine ecosystems and sustainably manage our fisheries for abundance.

Forty years ago today, Alaska’s steel artery – the Trans Alaska Pipeline System – pumped its first barrel of oil, and 17 billion more have followed since. It is impossible to overstate the importance of TAPS to Alaska: supporting our schools and public services, building a strong economy, and bringing countless opportunities to Alaskans. Looking forward to many more years of a full and functional pipeline. Happy Birthday, TAPS!

A few of the interns in my D.C. office had a great tour of the White House this morning. If you are visiting our nation’s capital, be sure to get in touch with us in advance so we can help coordinate tours, and ensure you make the most out of your visit. Find more info at: https://sen.gov/KPZW

I wanted to share with you my thoughts on healthcare reform as the Senate approaches consideration of a new proposal. While I am committed to repealing the Affordable Care Act, I will not vote for a bill that will make things worse for Alaskans.

Happy Solstice, Alaska! I wish I could be there under the midnight sun, and I really wish I was in Fairbanks for the annual Midnight Sun baseball game, which starts at 10:00 tonight and goes until the wee hours. If you’re in the area and you haven’t been, it’s definitely something you should experience.

In the coming days, I will read every word of the Better Care Reconciliation Act closely to see if Alaska-specific issues are addressed. Such issues include stabilizing the Alaska insurance market, reversing the trend of dramatically increasing costs, and providing a sustainable and equitable path forward for Medicaid.   The current system is not sustainable for Alaskan individuals, families and small businesses. Many Alaskans are being forced to buy insurance that they can’t afford and can’t use. Overall, I believe that we can do better for our state and our country, but I will not vote for a bill that will make things worse for Alaskans.

I want to thank President Trump for signing the VA Accountability Act into law, the product of bipartisan work and cooperation in the Veterans’ Affairs Committee. This legislation is an important step toward restoring the trust and confidence of veterans in the VA. Secretary Shulkin now has the tools and flexibility needed to change the culture within the VA by firing employees who are ill-serving our veterans. As such, I expect to see swift action to ensure veterans receive the care they have earned and deserve.

Julie and I had the honor of attending Korea-Alaska Friendship Day in Anchorage. The Consular Office of the Republic of Korea and the Korean community of Anchorage organized a wonderful celebration, including incredible performances by classical opera singers from New York and the world-renowned NANTA performers. Today also honored the 67th anniversary of the start of the Korean War and we were humbled to be able to thank the many Korean War veterans in attendance for their service in this noble war. Thank you to Deputy Consul General Ms. Ohkeum Kwon for inviting me to participate on this special occasion.

I’ve been relentlessly focused on educating leadership about how big of an outlier Alaska is as it relates to healthcare and insurance costs. I spent the weekend poring over the Senate’s Better Care Reconciliation Act to see how this draft addresses these costs and other healthcare issues in the state, and I’ll continue to do so going forward. You can review the bill for yourself at: https://goo.gl/NWo5vV

I support Senate leadership’s decision today to withhold a vote on the Better Care Reconciliation Act in order to better address the concerns of members. I also appreciate being invited to the White House with my colleagues for a very productive meeting with President Trump and Vice President Pence.  As we move forward, I will continue to work on the draft of the Senate bill to make it better for Alaskans by continuing to focus on what’s worked under the Affordable Care Act—like continued coverage for those with preexisting conditions— and to replace it with a bill that will better serve our state.  I believe that we can achieve those goals by stabilizing our health insurance system, giving Alaska the flexibility to craft plans that work for our citizens to address the high cost of healthcare and insurance, and providing a sustainable and equitable path forward for Medicaid.  Like most one-size-fits-all approaches from Washington D.C., the Affordable Care Act is not working for many Alaskans. Premiums and deductibles have skyrocketed for the middle class. The director of Alaska’s Division of Insurance said that our market is in "chaos." The current situation in the healthcare market in Alaska and nationally is not sustainable. Something has to be done, and it has to be done soon.

My Anchorage office has been spruced up with some incredible works of art, each of which have deeper meaning behind them. The pieces, on loan from the Chris Kyle Patriots Hospital in Anchorage, were crafted by veterans and service members being treated for PTSD and substance addiction. I am so grateful for the incredible work being done by CKPH and other organizations to help heal our men and women in uniform who have sacrificed so much for us.
Before the Fourth of July recess, I wanted to update you on what we’ve been doing in the Senate as it relates to healthcare, and what Alaska-specific issues I’ll be working on going forward.
Today I had my Marine Corps physical fitness test: 17 pull ups, 100 sit-ups, and a 22:40 three-mile run!

Julie, the girls and I are fishing on the Yukon this week, enjoying the beauty of our incredible state. We want to thank the brave men and women in uniform who have sacrificed to keep America free and safe, especially those serving far away from their loved ones right now. To all Alaskans - Have a joyful and peaceful Independence Day!

Today Alaskans awoke to disturbing news that North Korea tested a missile that some experts say may be able to reach Alaska in the near future. Now more than ever, it's imperative for Alaskans and the rest of the nation that we be prepared. That's why I recently introduced a bill - the majority of which was included in the National Defense Authorization Act passed out of committee last week - that will significantly boost our missile defense capabilities and keep America safe.

Another big achievement for Alaska’s young, rising track star Allie Ostrander who won her first Mt. Marathon women’s championship yesterday after winning the girls’ division a number of times in past years. Congratulations, Allie, and also to Scott Patterson, Luke Jager and Molly Gellert on taking home the men’s, boys’ and girls’ titles!

I had the honor of recognizing an extraordinary man – and a great American – on the Senate floor recently: Solomon "Sol" Atkinson, of Metlakatla. Sol was a member of the very first Navy SEAL team created by President Kennedy in 1962. In addition to his remarkable military career, including three combat tours in Vietnam and numerous medals and awards, Sol never stopped giving back to his country and community. He has served on the school board, Indian Community Council, as mayor of his hometown, and as a strong advocate for his fellow veterans. Thank you, Sol, for your inspiring example, and for being our Alaskan of the Week.

For weeks, I have been calling on Senate leaders to suspend the August recess so that we can address the important issues we were sent here to work on - reforming our onerous regulatory system and tax code, fully supporting our military’s mission, fixing the unraveling disaster of Obamacare, and getting our economy growing again. I appreciate Majority Leader McConnell today deciding to postpone the August recess. It is time to get results for the American people.

Earlier this week, the Missile Defense Agency conducted a successful test of the Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (THAAD) system at the Pacific Spaceport Complex on Kodiak Island. The test provides further confirmation that we have the capability to defend our bases, our troops, and our allies in places like Japan, South Korea, and Guam against rogue nations like North Korea. Now more than ever before, Alaska is showing itself to be the cornerstone of U.S. missile defense.

I want to congratulate Major General Mark O’Neil on assuming command of U.S. Army Alaska (USARAK), and also thank Major General Bryan Owens for leading our Arctic Warriors for the past two years, as well as his many years of service to our country. Alaskans are proud of the men and women who serve in USARAK—one of the toughest, most capable expeditionary forces anywhere in the world.

During last year’s presidential campaign, I expressed concerns about how a future Trump presidency might regard the importance of our allies. The President’s visit today to France, America’s oldest ally, on the 100-year anniversary of the U.S. entry into World War I, as well as his strong affirmation of NATO’s Article 5 last week, demonstrates the new administration’s understanding that our alliances are a tremendous asset amid the myriad of geopolitical challenges taking place today. We are an ally-rich nation and our adversaries are ally-poor—a fact that is absolutely essential to ensuring our own security and the cause of peace and stability around the world.

A number of my staff members have served or are currently serving in the military, bringing with them skills and discipline that are great assets to my office. Today, that group got a little bigger. I had the honor of swearing one of my staffers, Micah McKinnis, into the Alaska Air National Guard. We are proud of Micah and all those who seek to serve and defend our great country.

The Trump Administration has an important decision coming up soon — whether to certify Iran’s compliance with the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, signed by the Obama Administration in 2015. I firmly believe that Iran is in violation of the deal. In a recent op-ed, I laid out a strategy for the administration that emphasizes American leadership and a path forward with regard to the significant threat Iran poses.

Last week, we saw another horrific murder of a law enforcement officer – NYPD officer Miosotis Familia – a mother of three targeted while sitting in her car. Peggy Noonan writes in the Wall Street Journal, "It should be a major, sustained national story when cops are killed for being cops. Yet each incident never gels into a theme. The media caravan moves on." I recently reintroduced the “Protect Our Heroes” Act, which would make the assault or killing of a public safety officer a federal crime, and would add an additional penalty for luring an officer to a location for an ambush attack. This legislation would send a powerful signal that we acknowledge this disturbing spike in attacks and are willing to act to have our brave officers' backs.

I joined Fox and Friends yesterday to discuss my effort to shorten the Senate's August recess so that we can deliver results for the American people, and some preliminary thoughts on the latest draft of the Better Care Reconciliation Act. Please take a listen.

One of Alaska’s-own—Jack Green, of Anchorage—led the USA Junior Boys Soccer Team to victory at the 20th World Maccabiah U16 Soccer Championship in Israel this weekend. The competition draws more than 10,000 athletes from over 80 countries, including 1,100 from the U.S. Congratulations, Jack, on your impressive achievement and for representing Alaska so well!

I had the opportunity last week to recognize a legend of Alaska’s aviation industry, Gene Zerkel, as our Alaskan of the Week. A member of the Greatest Generation, Gene has always had a passion for flying, from his service in the U.S. Air Force to his years promoting safety within the aviation industry. Gene passed away recently, and I want to extend my condolences to his wife, Joyce, and ten children during this difficult time.

I’m frustrated that the Senate couldn’t reach a consensus on a bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act and replace it with one that would have been good for the country and for our state. But I will continue to press for a path forward.  Alaskans are paying the highest health insurance premiums in the country. We are down to one insurer on the individual market where premiums have gone up more than 203 percent, averaging over $1,000 for just an individual Alaskan. While many Alaskans may now be covered—which is a good thing—thousands of hard-working Alaskans can’t afford to pay their premiums and deductibles and have been forced to go without insurance and endure the federal fine for opting out.  In 2015, I, along with 51 of my Republican colleagues in the Senate, voted for repeal Obamacare. Unfortunately, President Obama vetoed the bill. Given the opportunity, I intend to keep my promise to Alaskans to vote again for repeal, and continue to work with my colleagues to come up with a replacement that works for Alaska.
I'm keeping my friend Senator John McCain in my prayers. My colleagues in the Senate & all Americans stand behind this American hero in his fight against cancer.

Last night, President Trump announced his nomination of Joe Balash, my chief of staff, as the next Assistant Secretary of the Interior for Land and Mineral Management. While I’m sad to see Joe leave, his departure is a big gain for Interior Secretary Zinke, the Department of Interior, the United States and Alaska. His wealth of knowledge and passion for Alaska – and more broadly, federal land issues – cannot be overstated. His advice and counsel on natural resource matters will be invaluable as Secretary Zinke and the Trump administration chart a new path toward American energy dominance. Alaska can and should be a critical element of this important national objective.

The federal government has for years been telling the people of King Cove that protecting birds is more important than their health and safety. This is unconscionable. Today the House passed legislation authorizing a simple land exchange to build a 11-mile life-saving road to Cold Bay. I want to thank Congressman Young for his fierce determination to get this bill passed in the House, and will work with Senator Lisa Murkowski to pass it in the Senate. The residents of King Cove deserve nothing less.

I had the opportunity today to share with my colleagues one of the many extraordinary things about Alaska – our cuisine – and also highlight some of the local farms and businesses that offer up the best of Alaska. On the menu was fresh salmon and halibut, succulent carrots and potatoes, kohlrabi, “snow apples” (turnips), ripe cucumbers and tomatoes, barley couscous, and Black Gold brownies – all of which made the 7,000-mile flight to DC. I encouraged each senator to get word back to their constituents that if they’re looking for a great “foodie” trip—or the trappings of a delicious home meal—it’s time to look North.

The G.I. Bill has long been a meaningful incentive for enlistees who want to pursue their education and career dreams during or after their military service. This week, I co-introduced legislation to update the post-9/11 G.I. Bill with several commonsense reforms and technical fixes that will enhance this vital benefit for veterans and service members. Most notably, the legislation would create a "Forever" G.I. Bill, eliminating the arbitrary 15-year rule and enabling veterans to utilize their earned benefits at the point in their lives that they determine is best for them. It is imperative that we continue to invest in those who serve and bravely sacrifice to keep us safe.

Every day in D.C., I’m reminded of what a lion Senator Ted Stevens was in the Senate. And in Alaska, we’re reminded everyday of how hard he worked to make our state great. In addition to being brilliant on policy, he was a great outdoors enthusiast. Ted loved our state for all it was, and all it could be. He loved the people, and he loved the landscape. So every year, on the fourth Saturday of July, we honor Senator Stevens by doing what he most loved, and would want us to do: Get Out and Play!

There’s no better place to be in the world than Fairbanks during Golden Days. Julie and I had a fantastic time taking in the sun, food and festivities – handing out candy in the grand parade, checking out the many different booths, and tasting the mouth-watering creations of the most talented barbeque connoisseurs in Alaska.

Alaska is the proud home of more veterans per capita than any other state – and today is National Hire a Vet Day! I’m honored to have a number of veterans serving in my office – both in Alaska and in DC. As the Republican Senate Co-Chair of the Congressional Veterans Jobs Caucus, I encourage Alaska employers to extend opportunities to veterans who carry skills and discipline that are extremely valuable to any organization.

I’m heartened that my colleagues in the Senate today kept their promises to their constituents to begin the process to repeal and repair the Affordable Care Act. Now, the Senate will start an open amendment process that will begin to consider various solutions to address the harm being done by this Act.   Since December, I have met with and heard from thousands of Alaskans and I’ve taken their concerns into account throughout this process. While many Alaskans received coverage under Obamacare, more than 23,000 declined to buy outrageously expensive plans they can’t even use, many of them opting instead to pay a fine to the federal government. This is unacceptable.  As the Senate considers legislation and amendments, I will continue to focus on repealing Obamacare’s taxes and mandates, and work to increase support for rural states, like Alaska, with extremely high insurance costs. I will also continue to work to put Medicaid on a sustainable and equitable path, with maximum flexibility given to states to tailor systems that meet their residents’ needs. Lastly, I will continue to fight for significant resources to combat the opioid epidemic taking place in Alaska and across the country.   As we go forward, I will continue to relentlessly advocate for Alaska’s interests and will not vote for a bill that makes things worse for Alaskans.

This afternoon, prior to the Senate’s vote, I joined Fox News to discuss the promises made by many senators to their constituents with regard to the unraveling Affordable Care Act. The world’s greatest deliberative body – the Senate – now has an opportunity to debate an issue of great importance to all Americans.

Alaska vets – this Saturday, July 29, from 10:00am and 2:00pm, the Alaska VA is hosting a Wellness Fair, Claims Clinic and Motorcycle Rally in Anchorage. Veterans and their family members will have the opportunity to file claims, discuss billing, meet with VA representatives, and check out more than 29 health booths and vendors. We will keep you updated on other upcoming opportunities to engage with the VA around the state as they come up. As always, if you are experiencing problems with your VA care, please give my staff a call at 907.271.5915.

Three years ago, as I crisscrossed the state, I heard story after story of families and small businesses who were experiencing fewer healthcare choices and paying skyrocketing costs for health insurance. After hearing those stories, I pledged to help those Alaskans who were hurting. Since coming to the Senate, the situation in Alaska and across the country has only gotten worse, and I’ve continued to hear even more heartbreaking stories. My staff and I have worked relentlessly to honor my pledge. Tonight, my heart aches for these hard-working Alaskans and their families, but they should know that I’m not done fighting.
Wrapping up a great weekend in Southeast, including stops in Ketchikan, Klawock, Craig and Metlakatla, with a visit with the Ketchikan Daily News—at the airport!

I had a great chat this afternoon with Senator Murkowski’s newest batch of summer interns, coming from Interior, Anchorage, Sitka, Mat-Su and the Kenai Peninsula. They described their exciting plans for college and beyond – many considering public service in one form or another. I’m excited to see what the future has in store for these exceptional young Alaskans.

Yesterday, I chaired a Senate Commerce Subcommittee hearing on the reauthorization of the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Act. Among our witnesses was Alaskan Chris Oliver, testifying for the first time as NOAA’s Assistant Administrator for Fisheries. The Magnuson-Stevens Act has played a vital role in protecting Alaska’s abundant fish stocks. I look forward to working with Administrator Oliver and my fellow senators on an MSA reauthorization that will support a stable food supply, recreational opportunities, and plentiful fishing and processing jobs that provide for vibrant coastal communities. You can see the full hearing here: https://sen.gov/1NLQ

The Senate unanimously passed the POWER Act yesterday, legislation introduced by Senator Heitkamp and me to help expand pro bono legal assistance for victims of domestic violence. The POWER Act will encourage lawyers across the country to get involved and help victims who too often fear or are unfamiliar with the justice system. I call on the House to swiftly move to pass this commonsense bill, so we can get it onto President Trump’s desk as soon as possible.

You may have seen a piece in the Alaska Dispatch News recently about Mark Braudis, an extraordinary Alaskan who overcame great odds to raise his family after the tragic death of his wife. In spite of the challenges they faced, six of Mark’s seven kids have joined the U.S. Marine Corps, and the seventh is pursuing a degree in electrical engineering from UAA. Mark’s example serves as inspiration for us all, and I’m proud to have shared his story on the Senate floor today.

Alaskans and all Americans rely on the U.S. Coast Guard to defend our nation when threats emerge, protect our waterways from environmental dangers and illegal fishing, and conduct rescue operations for those in crisis. As chair of the Senate Commerce Subcommittee on Oceans, Atmosphere, Fisheries, and Coast Guard, I had the honor of leading this year’s reauthorization of the Coast Guard—legislation supporting their mission and advancing the Coast Guard’s ability to operate in the Arctic. On behalf of a grateful state and nation, I want to wish all Coasties a Happy Birthday! Semper Paratus.

I had the honor of speaking yesterday at the national Veterans of Foreign Wars headquarters to celebrate the Senate’s unanimous passage of legislation I cosponsored creating a “Forever” G.I. Bill and eliminating the 15-year expiration date for vets to use their benefits. I look forward to this very important piece of legislation being signed into law, and I’m excited for what these reforms will mean for so many patriotic Alaskans and their families.

Individuals suffering from a terminal illness and their family members are faced with an anguishing struggle for wellness. In many cases, these patients want the opportunity to pursue experimental drugs or equipment, even if the odds are long. They should have that right. The Right to Try Act, passed in the Senate this week, removes the threat of federal interference, allowing states to pass laws that fit the needs of their residents. I thank my colleagues, under the leadership of Senator Ron Johnson, for passing this commonsense legislation that may give families in harrowing circumstances a glimmer of hope.

Over the course of years and decades, marine debris deposited in the ocean half a world away inevitably finds its way to Alaska's coastal communities and ecosystems. I'm proud to report that senators from coastal and landlocked states alike – from both parties – voted unanimously last week to pass the Save Our Seas Act, legislation I introduced earlier this year to tackle the marine debris crisis along America's coasts and help ensure that Alaska remains the super-power of seafood for generations to come. I encourage my colleagues in the House to move swiftly, so that we can reauthorize NOAA’s vital Marine Debris Program and enact other measures to clean up Alaska’s waters and protect our marine environment.

We’ve seen troubling news today suggesting North Korea may now have the capability to miniaturize a nuclear warhead, and reported threats by the regime against the U.S. territory of Guam. I joined Dana Perino on Fox News Channel this evening to discuss these developments as well as my legislation, the Advancing America’s Missile Defense Act, which seeks to strengthen and improve the reliability, capability, and capacity of U.S. homeland missile defense.

I spent the past two days at a U.S. military exercise focused on countering weapons of mass destruction (CWMD) with the Commander of U.S. Special Operations Command (USSOCOM), General Raymond Thomas, and many of the troops he leads. These highly trained special operations forces are some of the most intelligent, patriotic, and committed men and women I have ever met, and of course there were Alaskans among them!  USSOCOM recently took over the lead role for our nation's CWMD mission. In my Senate Armed Services oversight role, I am focused on making sure that these brave men and women get the resources and training they need for their critical CWMD mission. America is in good hands with these dedicated, silent warriors protecting us during these turbulent times.

I want to sincerely thank the thousands of Alaskans who have written me regarding health care reform, those who have participated in my numerous town halls and health care roundtables across the state, and those who have called and visited my offices. I’ve written a detailed letter discussing the recent health care reform legislative process, and the key elements of the Senate’s proposed legislation with an explanation of the challenges, opportunities, and ACA problems that the BCRA was intended to address. You can find my letter at: https://sen.gov/KPN8

The sight of white supremacists and neo-Nazis marching in an American city - or anywhere for that matter - is a disgrace. Their hateful ideology, which seeks to undermine the dignity of people based on their race, is antithetical to American ideals and values. I welcome the news that the U.S. Justice Department is investigating this incident of domestic terrorism, including the tragic murder and injury of peaceful protesters. As Americans, we must stand united in rejecting bigotry and racism, and those who seek to divide us.
SoHi football posted an impressive feat on Friday - a state record, in fact - clinching their 50th straight victory. Great job to the SoHi Stars, and to all of our talented young athletes!

Yesterday I had the opportunity to welcome Nancy Wallace, director of the NOAA Marine Debris Program, to Alaska. We had a great discussion with Peter Murphy, Alaska regional coordinator of the NOAA Marine Debris Program, Chris Pallister, director of Gulf of Alaska Keeper,and Molly McCammon, director of the Alaska Ocean Observing System. Director Wallace’s visit sends a strong signal that the federal administration has its attention on Alaska when it comes to marine debris, and is engaged with stakeholders and those on the ground working to keep our shores clean. Legislatively, our next objective is to move my Save Our Seas Act through the House, and get this important bill to the President’s desk.
Anything less than complete and unambiguous condemnation of white supremacists, neo-Nazis and the KKK by the president of the United States is unacceptable. Period.

The Blood Bank of Alaska serves as a vital resource for Alaskans and health institutions across the state, especially in times of crisis. In addition to collecting more than 24,000 units of blood each year, the Blood Bank is also conducting some pioneering work in the use of blood treatments to combat cancer. Thank you to CEO Bob Scanlon and Dr. Ian Van Tets for the tour of this facility.

Our hearts go out to the people of Spain in the wake of this morning's tragic terrorist attacks in the streets of Barcelona. The scourge of radical Islamist terrorism has taken thousands of innocent lives, but our resolve to defeat those who seek to destroy freedom and peace in our time will not waver. America stands together with our friends in Spain in mourning the loss of their fellow countrymen.

I want to thank the staff at Anchorage Neighborhood Health Center for the incredible work they do, and for inviting me to celebrate Community Health Center Week. Alaska is home to 160 community health centers, constituting 10 percent of all community health centers in the country. These facilities serve Alaskans in need, including those living in rural areas. I have been a strong supporter of increasing funding for our community health centers, including during the Senate's recent healthcare debate, and I'll continue to work to increase funding for these vital facilities.

Before the Senate gaveled out for the August recess, I spoke on the floor in recognition of Kathy Heindl, of Kenai. Kathy devotes a great deal of time each summer to cleaning the Kenai River, and educating anglers on how to protect the banks from erosion and stay safe on the river. She is also the recipient of the Kachemak Heritage Land Trust’s King Maker Award. Thank you, Kathy, for working to preserve our environment and fisheries for future generations, and for being our Alaskan of the week.

The Ted Stevens Marine Research Institute in Juneau today celebrated its 10th anniversary. Nobody has done more to advance fisheries and ocean research than Ted. He, along with Congressman Young and others, wrote the Magnuson Stevens Act (MSA), the seminal piece of legislation that created the modern fisheries management system, and the best managed fisheries in the world. We all miss Ted, but his memory lives on: in our towns and cities, in our hearts and in our oceans. Thanks for all of the work that’s being done by the Foundation to keep that memory alive.

I want to extend my thoughts and prayers for the missing and injured sailors of the USS John S. McCain and their families today. I fully support Admiral John Richardson's global operational pause for the Navy in the wake of this tragedy and the USS Fitzgerald collision in June. I am calling for Senate Armed Services Committee hearings on these matters - we are losing too many of our nation’s finest to operational and training accidents.

I commend President Trump for his strong speech last night outlining a revised strategy for Afghanistan. I am encouraged that the President –  following recommendations from Secretary Mattis and others – outlined clear principles to govern our continued presence there. Ensuring that Afghanistan does not again become a safe haven for global radical Islamic terrorist operations remains a fundamental U.S. national security interest. It is particularly significant that the President indicated U.S. involvement going forward would be based on strategic considerations rather than arbitrary timelines, and that he emphasized increasing pressure on Pakistan to eliminate terror safe havens as well as working with our allies and partners in the region.   In this regard, I was pleased to see the President publicly recognize the strategic importance of India’s economic and development assistance in Afghanistan, something that I have consistently worked to promote. As a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, I look forward to hearing more details from the Department of Defense on the implementation of this strategy in the near future.

I am live on the Kenai hosting a U.S. Senate Commerce Committee hearing regarding the reauthorization of the Magnuson-Stevens Fisheries Conservation Act. We'll be hearing from stakeholders and experts from Alaska and across the country about the successes and challenges of MSA, and how best to manage our fisheries going forward. Watch it live:

Alaska is full of entrepreneurs. On the Kenai, I had the opportunity to meet with a few of them. Pam Parker owns and operates "Everything Bagels," with delicious coffee and treats. Teresa Graves has operated Summit Dry Cleaners since 1991. Kelcey Morris opened Maxim Hair Designs just five years ago. Amie Smithwick operates Steamer Trunk Consignment Shop - one I know my girls would love to visit. Sue Mann shares her artistic creations at Artzy Junkin, loved by locals and tourists alike. I was so impressed with each of these Alaskans for their courage to take risks and pursue their dreams at the same time extending opportunities to their fellow Alaskans.

Earlier this week, Admiral Paul Zukunft, Commandant of the U.S. Coast Guard, joined me in Nome, Shishmaref, Cold Bay and King Cove, as well as a visit to the CG Cutter Healy operating in the Bering Sea. The trip highlighted Alaska’s unique role in our nation’s security, as well as the challenges and economic opportunities our rural communities face as they see increased vessel traffic. I thank the Admiral for making the trip, the brave men and women of the Coast Guard carrying out their mission, and the many gracious Alaskans who greeted us.

Americans on the Gulf Coast are suffering in the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey, a devastating storm that has flooded communities and left many people injured and homeless. I want to commend the Alaska Red Cross, the brave men and women of the Alaska National Guard and the U.S. Coast Guard, and other Alaskan volunteers for heading south to help those in need. We continue to pray for the first responders and all those whose lives have been upended by this terrible disaster.

I want to thank all of those who attended the Transportation Summit that I held last Thursday in Anchorage with U.S. Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao. She was able to hear from a wide variety of representatives from our transportation industry about the unique challenges we face in moving goods and services. It was also a great reminder of our immense opportunities—first and foremost our people who are absolutely committed to making our state better for all.

Last August, more than 400 Alaskans gathered at Mat-Su College for the Alaska Wellness Summit: Conquering the Opioid Crisis. This August, we held another summit examining the progress being made to combat the addiction epidemic. I want to thank our speakers: Michelle Overstreet and Michael Carson with MYHouse, Alaska's Chief Medical Officer Dr. Jay Butler, Andy Jones with Project Hope - and our panelists: Karl Soderstrom and Kerby Kraus with Fiend2Clean, Kara Nelson with Haven House, Anthony Bielet with Cook Inlet Tribal Council's Peer Network, and Philip Licht with Set Free Alaska. I also want to thank Fiend2Clean, Thrive Mat-Su and CITC for organizing a productive community discussion as we work to turn the tide.

For years, Alaskans have been calling for the construction of a 10-mile-long, single-lane, life-saving road between King Cove and Cold Bay, and there is hope now that we have a federal administration finally willing to listen. The mayor and people of King Cove have a message for DC: Let’s start digging!

CNN came to Alaska recently to highlight the brave men and women of the Alaska National Guard’s 49th Missile Defense Battalion—the 300 protecting 300 million—and our nation’s missile defense assets at Fort Greely, “home to America’s last resort against a launched ICBM” from North Korea. I appreciated the opportunity to sit down with CNN and make the case for my Advancing America’s Missile Defense Act, which would strengthen the reliability, capability and capacity of our missile defense system.
Never gets old waking up to a momma moose and her calves relaxing in the back yard!
Checking out the 1,231.5 pound award-winning pumpkin, and the enormous runners up at the Alaska State Fair. How much pie do you think these could make?

The Commerce Department this week announced the U.S. economy grew at 3% in the most recent quarter — closer to the historic level of robust American growth that we need. I will continue to fight to get our economy growing again so that we can bring about new opportunities for workers in Alaska and across the country to find good jobs and support their families.

While in the Mat-Su, I stopped by Alaska Picker, founded by Becky Green, a Palmer Police and Fire dispatch supervisor, and Kelly Turney, a retired Palmer police officer. The popular shop has an incredible collection of Alaskan antiques and artifacts from ages past: Signs, furniture, dish-ware, books, toys, artwork, vehicle parts and other vintage household items. The pair have also collected priceless historical items dating back to World War II and Alaska’s rich history since. Congratulations, Kelly and Becky, on turning your novel idea into a bustling local business!

This week, I stopped by one of several rehabilitation courts offered in Alaska — the Anchorage Veterans Court, which serves veterans whose criminal offenses often display symptoms of post-traumatic or combat-related stress. The court, one of the first of its kind in the nation, brings together a team of attorneys, mentors, mental health treatment providers, and a judge to ensure justice is served while giving the veteran an opportunity to change course, receive treatment, and become productive, law-abiding members of the community. I appreciate the inspiring work being done by the mentors, the Alaska Department of Law, the Alaska Court System and other partners to change lives for the better.

Today was a bittersweet day in the Sullivan office. We said goodbye to a fantastic young member of our team, Xavier Mason. Xavier began as an intern in DC, rose to the level of staff assistant in my Anchorage office, and is now headed to the University of Oxford to pursue a master’s degree. He is well known for his involvement in the Anchorage community and will be missed by many. We wish Xavier all the best — and hope he will come back to the Last Frontier after this new adventure! If you are interested in interning in my Washington, DC office, you can learn more at: http://www.sullivan.senate.gov/services/internships

I had a great time meeting with the bright young Alaskans at Mat-Su Career & Tech High School which aims to prepare students for a successful post-grad career, learning from local employers about opportunities as they pursue their studies and attain new skills. I stopped by the history class of Mr. Lanphier, a former sergeant in the Marine Corps. I’m always excited to see veterans offering their talents and discipline back to the communities they love, and acting as mentors to the next generation of leaders. Thank you Principal Okeson, Superintendent Goyette and Assistant Principal Simmons for the tour of this impressive school!

A big thank you to the hard-working men and women of Alaska - our builders, public safety officers, salesmen, fishermen, pipe fitters, miners, nurses, educators, military service members, pilots, electricians, truck drivers, and so many more trades and professions that are vital to our communities. You make our state the best in the country and our country the best in the world. I hope all Alaskans are having a very happy and relaxing Labor Day.

Coastal Alaska communities have faced devastation in decades past from tsunamis, most notably in the aftermath of the ‘64 Good Friday earthquake. I visited the National Tsunami Warning Center in Palmer recently to learn more about the monitoring being done every hour of the day to keep Alaskans, and all Americans, safe. This Saturday, the Center is celebrating its 50th anniversary. If you’re in the Valley, stop by their open house between noon and 4pm. You’ll have the opportunity to experience a virtual earthquake, tour the seismic observatory, and speak with the scientists—some of the most prominent seismologists in the world—who track the data and issue those all-important warnings.

The DACA program was enacted without the approval of Congress and very likely exceeded President Obama’s authority under the Constitution. America is a nation of laws and a nation of immigrants. I believe we can remain faithful to both of these critically important ideals. Going forward, in addition to securing our border, it is important to keep in mind that the beneficiaries of the DACA program came to our country as children through no fault of their own. Most are hardworking, law-abiding members of our communities, including hundreds in Alaska. I intend to work with Republicans and Democrats to address these particular immigration cases through legislation both with compassion and a respect for the rule of law.

This morning, I had the opportunity to hear Alaska’s Director of Insurance, Lori Wing-Heier, speak to 30 of my Senate colleagues and me about stabilizing the individual health insurance markets. She then went on to testify in front of the Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee showcasing the innovative approach the State of Alaska has taken to stabilize our individual market. Alaska is the first state to be granted a 1332 waiver. I worked tirelessly with CMS to expedite the processing of our 1332 reinsurance waiver which brings much needed flexibility and funding to our vulnerable individual insurance market. You can watch full hearing here:
My girls and I had a blast on the water in Resurrection Bay recently – even the clouds were foreshadowing a successful day of “bites.” Sure enough, we came home with a haul.

I am out at JBER today to help give a strong send-off to the brave men and women of the 4-25 Infantry Brigade Combat Team deploying to Afghanistan. Alaskans could not be more proud of these Spartans as they prepare to deploy in support of Operation Resolute Support. You can watch the ceremony on this 360 live-stream provided by U.S. Army Alaska.

Over the past few years, Alaskans worked tirelessly to prevent the 4-25 Infantry Brigade Combat Team at JBER from being disbanded amidst planned Army reductions. Our community and the Arctic-tough warriors themselves successfully showed senior military leaders just how capable and lethal this unit is. As the 4-25 deploys to Afghanistan, many Alaskans have asked how they can continue to support our service members and their families. I encourage you to get in touch with the Armed Services YMCA of Alaska and the JBER USO. To our Spartans: We have your backs. Alaska loves its members of the military and we will support you with everything in us.

Julie and I are praying for the people of Florida as they weather through Hurricane Irma, and for the people living in the Caribbean who have already been devastated by the storm. To help victims, FEMA recommends donating to reputable recovery organizations where 100% of your resources go to relief efforts. I commend the many Alaskans who have helped victims of Hurricane Harvey, and now support our fellow citizens in danger along the eastern Gulf Coast.

I was honored to host 16 of the U.S. Air Force’s senior leaders in Alaska to discuss our state’s strategic location, amazing training grounds, and military-friendly communities – three factors that will shape the Air Force’s operations in the Arctic over the next 20 years. The generals and other senior leaders took the time to visit Utqiagvik, tour Eielson Air Force Base, fly through the Joint Pacific Alaska Range Complex (JPARC), and hear from Alaskans about why the Arctic is a region of increasing strategic importance. The Air Force continues to play a critical role in Alaska’s future.

A well-known member of the Interior community is headed south to Colorado. Lorna Shaw served as a staffer in the Legislature and for Senator Frank Murkowski for years before becoming a leader in the business community, serving with the Fairbanks Chamber of Commerce, Resource Development Council, and Alaska Miners Association. She has also been recognized for her exceptional volunteer work and as the 2014 UAF Business Leader of the Year. Best wishes, Lorna – we hope this journey brings you back to the Last Frontier again soon.

From 2006 to 2016, the Missile Defense Agency's budget has declined nearly 25 percent, and funding for testing has declined by nearly 83 percent. Meanwhile in just five years, North Korean dictator Kim Jong-un has conducted more missile tests – including another one just today – and over twice as many nuclear tests as both his father and grandfather combined. I spoke on the Senate floor about a provision I’ve included in this year’s National Defense Authorization Act to bolster our missile defense and deliver greater security for the American homeland.

Alaska lost a great matriarch with the passing of former First Lady Ermalee Hickel. She will be remembered as a wonderful mother, an active member of our community, and a role model for all of us. Our thoughts and prayers are with the Hickel family.

Today we keep in mind the brave men and women in uniform who’ve gone missing or been held captive while in service to our country, as well as their families who wait in anguish for news of their loved ones. You are not forgotten.

I had the honor of meeting with the President of Finland Sauli Niinistö this week, where we discussed his nation’s priorities for the chairmanship of the Arctic Council, which moved from the U.S. to Finland earlier this year. Finland and Alaska have a lot in common, seeing challenges and opportunities grow in the Arctic. President Niinistö also expressed his interest in the Save Our Seas Act and working with the U.S. to build global partnerships to combat the epidemic of trash filling the oceans and threatening our coastlines. My colleagues and I will continue to focus on strengthening America’s presence in the Arctic and America’s alliances with Arctic nations, including this important bilateral relationship with Finland.

The father of the U.S. Air Force, Gen. Billy Mitchell, famously testified that “whoever holds Alaska will hold the world.” Alaska’s strategic location is vital to the mission of the Air Force, which today celebrates 70 years defending freedom. Happy Birthday to all of Alaska’s brave airmen – active, reserve, guard, and veteran – and their families.

Today, I joined 88 of my Senate colleagues in passing the FY 2018 National Defense Authorization Act, a significant – and long overdue – step toward rebuilding America’s military strength. At the same time threats around the globe have grown in number and severity, the defense budget has declined by nearly one-quarter over the past several years. The Senate sent a powerful message to our Armed Forces, our allies, and our adversaries, that we intend to substantially increase military funding. From advancing missile defense and enhancing our Arctic interests to supporting our troops and reassuring our allies, I was proud to include provisions in this year’s bill that will both protect American citizens and help Alaska.

I spoke with Neil Cavuto today about the Graham-Cassidy proposal, which would send federal healthcare dollars back to the states to decide how best to meet the needs of their constituents. I’m still looking for more data on how this bill would impact Alaska, but the plan to give power back to the states—the laboratories of democracy—is very compelling. As we have seen with Obamacare, just as we have with so many decrees that come from D.C., a top-down, one-size-fits-all model doesn’t work for our state. I look forward to a committee hearing as soon as next week.

I wish the lieutenant all the best as she reports to the 1st Marine Division. Semper Fi.

I’m disappointed that we haven’t been able to replace the Affordable Care Act with a system that works for Alaska. The Graham-Cassidy Senate healthcare reform proposal would have sent federal healthcare dollars and decision-making back to the states—the laboratories of democracy—to decide how best to meet the needs of their constituents. As Alaskans know, our healthcare challenges are different from other states, and the top-down mandates, which are the foundation of the Affordable Care Act, simply haven’t worked for thousands of Alaskans.  The Graham-Cassidy bill, which I’m convinced would have brought more funds and more flexibility to Alaska, was compelling. Unfortunately, the process was rushed and we ran out of time to fully vet the data. I appreciate the collaborative work that the State of Alaska’s healthcare team put into this, and all of the hard work that Senators Graham and Cassidy undertook to understand and act on our issues. As a result of the delegation’s relentless work to educate our colleagues on Alaska’s challenges, I thoroughly expect that when this bill is reintroduced and reviewed, Alaska’s unique healthcare landscape will again be recognized, as it was in Graham-Cassidy.  Finally, it’s imperative that we continue to work toward a better healthcare system for Alaskans and all Americans. The Affordable Care Act has not worked as promised and continues to collapse across the country. We are now at a crossroads. One-third of my Democratic colleagues have signed onto a bill, introduced by Senator Bernie Sanders, which would force an estimated 155 million Americans off of their private insurance plans and into a healthcare system controlled and run by the federal government that would cost tens of trillions of dollars. The Graham-Cassidy bill would have brought significant federal resources to states, recognizing all of our unique healthcare challenges, and would have brought the decision-making closer to the people.

You may have read stories in recent years about a phenomenon known as harmful algal blooms (HABs), which can turn fresh water and seawater bright green or red when certain colonies of algae grow out of control. HABs actually pose a real threat to marine life, including shellfish and marine mammals. Yesterday the Senate passed legislation I’ve been working on with Senator Nelson (D-FL) to reauthorize S. 1057, the Harmful Algal Bloom and Hypoxia Research and Control Act through 2022. In other good news on this front, NOAA recently announced that UAF, the Sitka Tribe of Alaska, and the Southeast Alaska Regional Dive Fishery Association were among the recipients of a $742,941 award, funds that are made possible through the program reauthorized by S. 1057. These funds will help preserve the Southeast Alaska geoduck clam fishery. I’m glad to see the best Alaskan minds being tapped to conduct this important research.

Yesterday, I was glad to hear the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs, General Joe Dunford, signal his support for the substantial increase in ground-based interceptors (GBIs) at Fort Greely that I secured in this year’s defense authorization. As North Korea continues to aggressively test and develop its nuclear and ballistic missile technologies, we must continue to rapidly advance our own missile defense capabilities.

Each year, more than 44,000 Americans die by suicide – a staggering 122 suicides every day. Particularly troubling, Alaska has the second highest rate among the 50 states. I've joined a bipartisan group of senators in introducing the National Suicide Prevention Hotline Improvement Act to ensure this vital resource is effectively serving Americans who are struggling. If you or someone you know is suffering from suicidal thoughts, please do not hesitate in reaching out for help by calling the hotline at 1.800.273.TALK.

The legislation contains $74.8 million that I fought to include for the Essential Air Service (EAS), a vital program serving some 60 communities in Alaska. This bill, which reauthorizes the FAA through 2021, makes significant investments in aviation infrastructure and features many reforms and provisions important for Alaska.

We need policies that focus on reigniting growth: infrastructure investment, less burdensome regulations, igniting our energy potential, and tax reform. As we debate these policies, I will continue to ask what such reform will do to reignite the kind of historic economic growth that turned the American dream into a reality.

I got a great start to my day this morning with a long run through beautiful Juneau, enjoying the scenery. I was also able to stop by the USS Juneau Memorial to pay respects to nearly 700 sailors who died when the ship was sunk during the Naval Battle of Guadalcanal in WWII. Among those who perished were five brothers from Waterloo, Iowa: George, Francis, Joseph, Madison, and Albert Sullivan. As a result of the sacrifice of the Sullivan brothers, the Sole Survivor Policy was enacted, which protects family members from the draft or from combat duty if they have already lost family members in military service.

I was pleased to vote last night for a fiscally responsible budget which lays the foundation for tax reform and for unlocking Alaska's energy potential. This was another key step that we’ve recently accomplished in a decades long fight to allow Alaskans to produce energy in our state – something that Alaskans, Democrats, Republicans,  and independents, overwhelmingly support. More American energy production means more good-paying jobs, increased economic growth, and a stronger national security. More American energy production will also help to generate wealth, decrease our federal deficit, while fostering a more sustainable global environment. Because no one in the world produces energy more responsibly than Alaskans and Americans.

As a result, I’ve introduced a bill that would divide the Ninth Circuit and establish a new Twelfth Circuit with jurisdiction over the states of Alaska, Arizona, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, Oregon, and Washington. Today, I was honored to join Alaskan leaders and experts at the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee hearing today on responsibly developing a small slice of the 1002 Area of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. This development would create jobs, grow our economy, and strengthen our national security. When we don’t have to import energy from countries that don’t like us, or better yet, when we can export American energy to our allies like Japan and Korea, or even a country like China, this helps our national security and foreign policy. I thank Senator Lisa Murkowski for the great hearing and all the Alaskans who gave great testimony. Let’s get this done!

Today, language to open a small section of the 1002 area of ANWR passed the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources, chaired by Senator Murkowski. I thank her for her leadership in getting this through and to all the Alaskans who have voiced their support. This is one more step in a long process that could result in a decades-long dream of opening the area for safe and responsible resource development—creating good paying jobs and bringing in more state funds to help pay for public safety, education, and much needed infrastructure across Alaska. Increasing our domestic energy production will also strengthen our national security by stopping importation of energy from countries that don’t like us, and exporting energy to our allies. It’s a win for our country and a win for Alaska. Let’s get this done!
